COUNTRY: EUROPE (97%); FRANCE (94%); SPAIN (94%); ITALY (91%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (79%); AFRICA (79%); EASTERN EUROPE (73%); GERMANY (73%);
TEXT: The anti-corruption fever that led to more than 4,000 Italian politicians and businessmen being implicated in the exchange of bribes for government contracts appears to be spreading across the continent, to France, Spain, Germany and some East European countries. More than two years after Milan's prosecuting judges launched a probe that ultimately brought down Italy's postwar ruling establishment, magistrates in other European countries are chasing suspected scandals with such zeal that many political and business leaders are sweating over possible consequences. "We have touched just the tip of the iceberg," said Thierry Jean-Pierre, a French judge who has been pursuing corruption leads in high places for several years. "We still have not gotten close to exposing the worst abuses of power, but there is now a powerful determination, by the public and judges alike, to get to the root of institutional corruption." Jean-Pierre, whose celebrity helped him win election recently to the European Parliament, has published a "Black Book" describing what he calls common scams that have enriched French politicians and their party treasuries. Besides kickbacks on government contracts and arms sales abroad, he says one of the most popular forms of political financing has been the systematic skimming of development aid intended for France's former colonies in Africa. For years, Jean-Pierre and other French magistrates were hamstrung by their political masters in ruling parties on both the right and the left. But thanks to the heroic example of Italian prosecutors and to strong public support, French judges are displaying boldness in challenging corrupt practices that long went unpunished. Corruption is nothing new in Europe, where a culture of patronage, petty bribery and cash kickbacks has long been indulged as an emblem of Old World sophistication. But in recent months, a spate of high-profile arrests, growing sensitivity to white collar crime and new revelations about the endemic nature of corruption has shaken public confidence in government. In turn, the investigating judges have emerged in the public eye as the last defenders of honesty and altruistic virtue, while the politicians and businessmen they have placed under scrutiny are scrambling to salvage their reputations and justify what they contend was "business as usual." Several factors have driven the anti-corruption campaign in Europe. In Spain and France, the decentralization of political power over the past decade has enhanced the authority of local and regional authorities -- and expanded bribery possibilities. The rising cost of campaigning has left politicians and their parties strapped for cash and desperate for ways to raise it, even by illicit means. And the growth of European stock markets has forced many companies to lift the secrecy from their accounts. Jean-Luc Mathieu, a leading French economist, attributes the anti-corruption drive sweeping the continent to a belated backlash against the "get rich quick" ethics that overtook Europe, as well as the United States, during the economic boom of the 1980s. "The weakening of business morals and the occasions for corruption became so rampant that it was only a matter of time before investigations and condemnation would follow," Mathieu said. "And the desire for revenge is also stronger because the disparity between rich and poor has gotten bigger." Pierre Milza, a professor at France's Institute of Political Studies, says the passing of the Cold War has forced Western societies to examine their moral foundations, including corrupt practices that for years were overlooked in the interests of sustaining political stability. "Western democracies can now afford to look inward and examine their ethical bases because they are no longer so worried about questions of survival and security," he said. "As a result, corruption is being revealed much more than before in many industrial societies, including Japan." Many experts say the corruption issue in Europe could unleash political turmoil unless the public sees that justice is done. Even popular governments can plummet in public esteem with the first whiff of scandal. Spain's Socialist Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez, for example, has lost his once unassailable stature because of corruption charges that have stung his government. "None of our countries is immune to the disease of corruption, and the gangrene is spreading," said Peter Leuprecht, secretary general of the 32-nation Council of Europe. "We believe in pluralist democracy, the rule of law and respect for human rights, and all three are threatened by corruption." Leuprecht said that while France, Italy and other Western countries are making headway in exposing corruption, there are signs that the scourge of bribery is eroding public faith in the nascent democracies of Eastern Europe to the point of evoking nostalgia for cast-off communist dictatorships. Voters have cited disgust with corruption as a major reason for casting ballots for the successors of discredited communist parties. Under communism, East European bureaucrats might have pocketed a small bribe to let a farmer jump the line to get a new tractor. But now they are in positions to decide deals worth millions of dollars, Leuprecht says. The temptation to extort kickbacks is so strong for officials toiling on tiny salaries that a recent Council of Europe study estimates that corruption is adding 10 percent to 15 percent to consumer costs in Central and Eastern Europe. It is in France, however, where judges predict the most dramatic developments in exposing corruption may occur in the months to come. Presidential elections are scheduled early next year, and political maneuvering is likely to produce explosive charges on both the right and the left. Once held in check by the political power of the central government, French judges have not flinched from challenging imposing targets. Within the last two months, the chairmen of two of France's leading enterprises, Schneider and Alcatel Alsthom, have been jailed for interrogation about misappropriated funds. They were subsequently released and denied the charges, but the cases are still under scrutiny. The country's biggest water utilities are under fire for overcharging customers and making illegal political contributions to win public contracts. Jean-Pierre said two large corporations -- presumably the water companies Lyonnaise des Eaux and General des Eaux -- "are responsible for 80 percent of the political corruption in France." The companies have denied any wrongdoing. Meanwhile, judges have declared open season on politicians across the ideological spectrum. On the left, former Socialist ministers have been accused of embezzlement, while tycoon-turned-politician Bernard Tapie has been charged with fraud and tax evasion. On the right, two members of Prime Minister Edouard Balladur's cabinet are facing corruption charges, while the Gaullist mayor of Lyons is suspected of receiving stolen funds. Even more serious charges of corruption are encircling French President Francois Mitterrand as he nears the end of his 14-year reign. One of Mitterrand's closest friends, Roger Patrice-Pelat, was indicted on charges of insider trading shortly after the state-owned firm Pechiney took over American Can Co. in 1988. Patrice-Pelat died while the investigation was underway, but this month Alain Boublil, a former adviser to then-Economy Minister Pierre Beregovoy, received a two-year sentence for tipping off Patrice-Pelat. Another of Mitterrand's close friends, Francois de Grossouvre, who gave testimony in the Pechiney case, had complained about corruption surrounding the president shortly before committing suicide at his desk in the Elysee Palace in April. Grossouvre's lament about Mitterrand's friends and family profiting from his position did not expire with his passing. A book by investigative journalist Jean Montaldo recounting Grossouvre's charges of corrupt practices by the president's cronies, entitled "Mitterrand and the 40 Thieves," has soared to the top of best-seller lists, with readers buying up 375,000 copies within a month of publication.

COUNTRY: KENYA (95%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%);
TEXT: The International Monetary Fund, stepping up efforts to combat corruption in the developing world, has adopted a new policy of denying financial assistance to countries where graft threatens to undermine their economic recovery programs. And showing that it means business, the IMF -- which in the past has based most of its lending decisions strictly on economic criteria -- is cutting off a $ 220 million loan to Kenya because of the refusal of Kenyan authorities to clean up pervasive bribery and self-enrichment. Kenya's currency has plunged as much as 20 percent this week as a result. The moves are among the most significant in a series of recent measures taken against corruption by aid agencies, Western governments and international organizations. They come in the wake of criticism aimed at the IMF and other aid donors over the blind eye that they allegedly turned toward rampant bribe-taking in Zaire during much of Mobutu Sese Seko's 32-year reign. Mobutu's corruption and repression spurred a rebellion that toppled him in May, and the nation was renamed Congo. The IMF's new policy, enshrined in guidelines approved Monday by its board, does not mean that IMF money will be withheld from any country where payoffs are common. Rather, it amounts to a warning that the IMF may pull the plug on a country when it believes corruption to be so corrosive as to endanger the attainment of goals specified in a recovery plan. "Financial assistance from the IMF . . . could be suspended or delayed on account of poor governance," the guidelines state, "if there is reason to believe it could have significant macroeconomic implications that threaten the successful implementation of the program, or if it puts in doubt the purpose of the use of IMF resources." "The guidelines are very important," said Frank Vogl, vice chairman of Transparency International, an anti-corruption advocacy group. "It's long overdue that multilateral organizations involved in financing developing countries place on a par with macro policies the basic soundness of the government institutions with which they're dealing." The cutoff of the loan to Kenya, he added, "sends a signal, especially because the guidelines are being issued at around the same time." Kenyan President Daniel arap Moi blasted the IMF's decision as "purely political," according to press reports from Nairobi. The developments reflect a rising determination in Western capitals, especially Washington, to crack down on corruption. IMF Managing Director Michel Camdessus and World Bank President James D. Wolfensohn have vowed in major policy addresses to take action based on research showing that bribe-taking by public officials tends to impede development, because scarce government funds are funneled into unproductive investments to earn payoffs. The guidelines state that the IMF should not "interfere in domestic or foreign politics" of a borrowing country. But they call for its employees to point out the economic consequences of corrupt practices that they may perceive during the periodic consultations they hold with government officials from the IMF's 131 member countries. And in the cases of countries borrowing from the IMF that have been judged to be seriously plagued by corruption, its staff might insist, for example, on "the removal of individuals from involvement in particular operations where corruption had occurred," according to the guidelines. The Kenya loan was suspended late last week because anti-corruption measures the government was taking "fall short of meeting the clearly expressed concerns of IMF member countries in the area of governance," according to an IMF statement. The suspension came just before the board's approval of the guidelines. An IMF official said the move was "probably the first time that we have said openly that governance issues were at stake" in such a decision. The suspension followed the Kenyan government's dismissal of its top customs official, Samuel Chebii, who is widely regarded as a crusader for cleaning up corruption in the nation's notoriously graft-ridden ports.

COUNTRY: KENYA (94%); TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (94%); UZBEKISTAN (93%); INDONESIA (93%); CAMEROON (93%); NIGERIA (93%); AZERBAIJAN (92%); GERMANY (92%);
TEXT: LIKE music CD's, box office receipts and the world's richest people, corruption has its own top 10 list. For the last five years Transparency International, a nonprofit group based in Berlin that specializes in tracking global thievery, has released the annual Corruption Perceptions Index, ranking the world's most corrupt countries. Last week the group declared Cameroon, Nigeria, Indonesia, Azerbaijan, Uzbekistan, Honduras, Tanzania, Yugoslavia, Paraguay and Kenya as the world's most graft-ridden countries, populated by public officials who are much quicker to take bribes than their counterparts in countries like Denmark, New Zealand and Sweden. But while Transparency's work has been lauded by economists and other analysts for helping to make corruption a centerpiece of debates about economic development and public policy, critics say the group's hit list unfairly tars countries that may be no more corrupt than those ranked much lower on the list. Indeed, the critics say the media is so quick to latch on to top 10 lists that agencies like Transparency International have an obvious incentive to present their information that way to score public relations coups. All the attention generated by the Corruption Perceptions Index, and criticism that it tended to highlight poor countries without noting the role that industrialized countries play in fomenting corruption abroad, led Transparency to introduce yet another ranking last week -- the Bribe Payers Index. "One of the worries people have had is that the ranking is very misleading," Rafael di Tella, an economics professor at Harvard Business School and one of Transparency's outside advisors, said of the Corruption Perceptions Index. "Transparency International has become a slave to the success of the index and it doesn't want to address the problem." The problem, as Mr. di Tella and others see it, is that the data used to analyze corruption -- surveys, for example, of business executives' perceptions -- are so fuzzy that huge margins of error exist when assigning a numerical yardstick to graft. Johann Graf Lambsdorff, a German statistician responsible for orchestrating Transparency's numbers into a coherent whole, says critics of the list unfairly imply that his methodology is faulty when, in fact, the only issue is how the results of Transparency's surveys are presented. Even so, Mr. Lambsdorff says he is comfortable with his group's list. "A ranking is easier to convey information to a large public, like a football ranking," said Mr. Lambsdorff, a professor at Gottingen University. "We can clearly say that Denmark is cleaner than Germany and Germany is cleaner than Botswana. But in between there may be some problems -- saying that Kenya is cleaner than Tanzania, for example." But that is precisely the problem, say critics, pointing to Bolivia's Presidential election in 1997 as an example of the list's far-reaching influence. The former dictator Hugo Banzer won the Presidency that year on an anti-corruption platform bolstered by the release of Transparency's rankings shortly before the election -- rankings showing that corruption in Bolivia was worse than in many of its neighbors. Mr. Lambsdorff says Transparency cannot avoid having such an impact because elections are occurring in many countries when their rankings are released. "We keep on stressing that these are perceptions, not hard facts," said Frank Vogl, Transparency International's vice-chairman and co-founder. "You always have this problem of how to present the data." Nonetheless, the list has stirred dissent within the group's own membership. "Transparency's index was good when there were no other numbers available but we need to go further now," said Luis Moreno Ocampo, a prominent anti-corruption crusader in Argentina who is a member of Transparency's advisory council. "The issue is not which country is worse than another, the issue is how to solve the problem. We need to track where the money is going and who is stealing it." Mr. Moreno has been working with the World Bank to come up with new methods of measuring and presenting data on corruption. Daniel Kaufmann, a senior manager with the World Bank, says grouping countries in broad categories -- rather than ranking them -- is the fairest way to shine a spotlight on corruption. "The idea that Transparency International had is brilliant and now we all want to be more rigorous and circumspect when we analyze corruption," he said.  http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: AFRICA (99%); UNITED STATES (97%); NIGERIA (94%); GHANA (92%); ERITREA (92%); ETHIOPIA (92%); RWANDA (92%); UGANDA (92%); CAMEROON (79%); EUROPE (79%);
TEXT: ON his first trip to Africa two years ago, President Clinton dreamed out loud that his journey would be remembered in a hundred years as "the beginning of a new African renaissance." The president singled out four African heads of state whose free-market savvy would help revive the world's poorest continent. Since then, all four leaders -- in Uganda, Rwanda, Ethiopia and Eritrea -- have crippled their nations' economies by going to war. "We Americans are so desperate for good news on the continent that it is almost irresistible when we find a good man in Africa," said Edward P. Brynn, the former American ambassador to Ghana who greeted Mr. Clinton in Accra on the first leg of his 1998 trip. "The only way we seem to be able to identify success in Africa is through personalization." This weekend, on a return engagement in Africa, Mr. Clinton is again singing the praises of a good man in Africa. This time it's President Olusegun Obasanjo of Nigeria, a former general who was elected last year to lead Africa's most populous country. The Clinton administration has seized on Mr. Obasanjo, whose victory ended years of military dictatorship, as an anchor of democratic stability in restive West Africa. Again, though, there are risks. Mr. Obasanjo presides over a country that is fractured north from south by Islamic extremism. Nigeria is the second-most corrupt nation on earth (after neighboring Cameroon), according to Transparency International, a nonprofit anti-corruption group based in Germany. The former general's record on human rights has already been stained by his order for soldiers to destroy a town in the oil-producing Niger delta. His top aides have been selling their influence. Echoing the concern of many longtime Africa watchers, Mr. Brynn, a former No. 2 in the State Department's Africa bureau in the Clinton administration, says the United States must resist the temptation of "putting all our eggs in the personality basket." Mr. Brynn and many others argue that the only way for Americans to help Africa in a meaningful way is to join with European allies in the slow and painfully complex job of rebuilding institutions that have been falling apart for decades. Most important are the civil service, courts, the police and the military. After the collapse of colonialism in the 1960's and the spread of self-rule across most of Africa, early American efforts to aid newly independent states foundered when grants were badly monitored and often stolen by corrupt bureaucrats. In the past decade, the United States and other chastened donors have tended to steer clear of direct aid to governments. Instead, they funnel money through private and religious groups whose work in health care, basic education and small-business development can be monitored more closely. Neither of these approaches, though, has helped cure a continentwide pathology that has turned many African governments into predators. Poorly paid policemen, soldiers and civil servants often use their authority to serve themselves, rather than the public. "We failed to keep a real hands-on posture with aid," said Mr. Brynn, who served as a diplomat on the continent for 17 years in six different countries. "We allowed a small, clever class that inherited power from the colonial masters to take us to the cleaners. It will take a whole lot of time and money to turn Africa around." Except in Nigeria, South Africa and a handful of other countries, civil wars and corruption have swamped the African renaissance that Mr. Clinton envisioned two years ago. Much of the continent has resumed a long slide into poverty, war and disease -- a dismal trajectory that has excluded the region from the rapid free-market growth in much of the developing world. That painful pattern suggests that America's next president will be confronted by military and humanitarian crises in Africa that cannot be solved with foreign trips or inspiring speeches -- and quite possibly cannot be solved at all. Out of the 27 major armed conflicts in the world last year, 11 were fought in Africa. Five of the world's 10 most corrupt countries are in Africa, according to Transparency International. A peace deal for Sierra Leone, which the United States helped broker in 1999, collapsed back into war this spring, with United Nations peacekeepers taken hostage. As in Rwanda, where Mr. Clinton apologized two years ago for America's failure to prevent genocide in 1994, the continuing mess in Sierra Leone reveals an absence of international commitment to peacekeeping in Africa. THE AIDS pandemic has accelerated and is threatening to kill up to 25 percent of the population in some African countries. War in Congo has sucked in a half-dozen other African states and shows no signs of ending. A political and economic rot that African scholars call "failed-state syndrome" seems to be spreading from countries like Somalia and Sudan to what used to be models of stability -- Kenya, Ivory Coast and Zimbabwe. "It is a very frightening picture that we face in Africa," said J. Stephen Morrison, who left the State Department's policy planning staff last spring after four years of working on Africa policy. "It makes people exceedingly uncomfortable." Mr. Morrison, like many experts on Africa, agrees that the United States and European countries need to commit more money and more skilled people to rebuilding African governments. But like many others, he concedes that no one is sure about how to do it or how to persuade African leaders to allow what could be perceived as neocolonial meddling. "None of us have answers," he said. As director of the Africa program at the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Washington, Mr. Morrison is preparing a nonpartisan review of Africa policy during the Clinton years to help inform the next administration. "It is not clear that we have come to terms as a government and a nation about what is truly required to help Africa," he said. "If we come in on the cheap side, it is going to backfire. I think it is fair to say that the Clinton administration has suffered from rhetorical excess in Africa and deficits in terms of will and material commitment." But Mr. Morrison said the administration has been quick off the mark with significant economic and military assistance to Nigeria. Aid there has jumped from $7 million a year to more than $200 million since Mr. Obasanjo was elected in February 1999. On his trip this weekend, the president is not expected to offer much more money. The stakes are especially high in Nigeria. With 113 million people and huge oil and natural gas reserves, the country has the potential to drive an economic revival in all of West Africa. It is also one of few African states where the United States has a real strategic interest. Oil from Nigeria and Angola accounts for about 16 percent of America's supply, a figure projected to rise to more than 25 percent in the next decade. Washington is also counting on Nigeria's armed forces to restore peace in nearby Sierra Leone. American troops began arriving in Nigeria last week as part of a $20 million program to train and equip Nigerian and Ghanaian soldiers for peacekeeping. "Are we hanging too much on Obasanjo?" Mr. Morrison asked. "That is clearly a danger we face. We have to invest in institution building -- the military, the legislature, getting a handle on corruption. But we cannot do any of this stuff on the cheap. It has got to be sustained beyond this president and beyond Obasanjo." Spending by the United States government on development assistance in Africa has declined in the past decade. Aid to African nations peaked in the early 1990's at just over $800 million a year, dipped to $675 million in 1996 and grew this year to about $738 million. By comparison, Israel received about $900 million in economic support this year and Egypt about $760 million, according to the Congressional Research Service. The Republican majority in Congress has repeatedly cut the president's budget requests for Africa and has so far failed to approve an administration proposal to forgive about $475 million in African debt. Presidential trips notwithstanding, many experts on Africa (including several who have served in the Clinton administration) agree that Washington is not spending nearly enough money to sustain or even begin the kind of fundamental reform that is the only possible solution to the continent's complex problems. "You are left with a very weak hand," said Gerald Bender, a professor of international relations at the University of Southern California and an expert on Angola. "You do not have the means to initiate positive things or hold back problems like war." Mr. Bender and many other African specialists predict that until the United States is willing to work with Europe to pay for a kind of Marshall Plan for Africa, American presidents will have little choice but to follow Mr. Clinton's cheerleading example. Their role, by default, will be to heap praise on the good man of the hour in Africa and hope that he doesn't turn into a bad man who perpetuates his power by stealing his country's future.  http://www.nytimes.com

-- In his first seven weeks in office, President Vicente Fox has frustrated critics, and even some members of his cabinet, by moving slowly to investigate the rampant corruption and human rights violations of Mexico's authoritarian governments during the last seven decades. So far, Mexico's long-anticipated transition to a more democratic government has been marked by silence on wrongdoing committed during the long reign of the party Fox ousted, the Institutional Revolutionary Party, or PRI. The new administration has not released any evidence documenting theft of public funds, bribery, collusion with drug dealers, political killings and espionage by PRI regimes. Fox and members of his cabinet, many of whom were spied on and harassed while in the opposition, have made clear in interviews that debate over how far to delve into the sins of the past is divisive. While some say a reckoning is essential to building democracy, Fox has emphasized the priorities of pushing through political and economic reform. "We don't want to spend time on the past," Fox said in an interview. "Our time, our talent, our budget will be focused on the future." Critics say such comments suggest that Fox has decided against throwing open Mexico's dirtiest closets, as happened in South Africa, Germany and other countries that have undergone profound political transitions. They fear the government may pursue a few high-profile cases but avoid a systematic investigation into past abuses. Sergio Aguayo, a scholar and human rights activist, said it was too early in Fox's term to assess policies that are still not fully clear. But he said he worried that Mexico would not fulfill its "historical debt" to uncover the past. "One gets the impression that they don't have as a priority the opening of the files to establish the historical truth," Aguayo said. "The past has given us a heritage of bitterness. In any process of healing you need the truth." So cautious is the administration's approach that some of Fox's cabinet members have been refused access to the files kept on them under the PRI by the government intelligence service, the Center for Investigation and National Security, or Cisen. Under PRI rule, Mexico was a swamp of government corruption and abuse, with a thriving culture of bribery, theft and entitlement. The public has never had full explanations of the institutionalized fleecing of the public by senior officials, alleged secret government deals with drug barons and kidnappers, the 1968 massacre of demonstrators in Mexico City, the assassination of a leading presidential candidate in 1994, the disappearances of hundreds of anti-government activists over decades, or an obsessive government culture of wiretapping and political espionage. Fox, who campaigned on the promise of building the rule of law, said that at the end of his first 100 days in office he will submit proposals to Congress to revise the intelligence services, establish anti-corruption guidelines and perhaps call for a commission to investigate parts of the past. Some observers say Fox's approach is pragmatic and will help avoid distraction from his major goal of building a new political system in the face of a hostile Congress. Fox's national security adviser, Adolfo Aguilar Zinser, is one of several officials urging the government to move quickly to investigate the past. "In any political transition, you have to make difficult choices and trade-offs," Aguilar Zinser said in an interview. "But you have to do something, and that something has to be a lot. And we have to do it fast. Time is a critical factor here, because inertias can be created and you give time to those who are destroying records. If you let things drag on, nothing gets done." Although corruption and other forms of law-breaking have been endemic for years across government agencies in Mexico, much of the attention since Fox's election has focused on Cisen and whether Fox has the will to investigate its record and wrestle it back under honest government control. "He's scared of what he might find, so it's easier not to go after it too hard. And I think that's a big mistake," a top official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. Officially responsible for tracking rebel groups, drug traffickers and other threats to national security, Cisen instead became the ruling party's hatchet against its political enemies. Advisers to Fox call the organization, which has about 3,000 employees and a $ 120 million budget, a "monster." Its related network of clandestine intelligence agencies -- with alleged links to Telmex, the country's largest telephone company -- is so autonomous that Fox may not be able to fully rein it in. While part of the opposition, Fox was followed and wiretapped, and several members of his cabinet were hounded by Cisen. Even conversations by the president's octogenarian mother were taped by the government. Fox said in 1998, when he was governor of Guanajuato state, "Everything I say and do, I assume that I am being spied on." In 1984, Aguilar Zinser was kidnapped briefly and beaten by government thugs because of his criticism of the PRI's policies toward indigenous communities in Chiapas state. He said he believed that his private conversations were taped for years. Aguilar Zinser called the prompt reform of the agency "a thermometer of how much we want to change." Mariclaire Acosta, Fox's top human rights adviser, is one of several high-ranking officials who said they believed they were still being taped. Acosta said noise on the line and disruptions in service suggested that the tapping of her phones had increased since she joined Fox's cabinet. "I think the files have to be opened and the truth has to come out. That has to be done and it has to be done as soon as possible," she said in an interview. "Either you face the past and you come to terms with the past or you do not move forward. If you don't face it squarely, the ghosts come up to haunt you." Interior Minister Santiago Creel, who holds the second-most powerful post in Mexico after the president, said in an interview that the government was no longer taping politicians. He said he had "found things out" about past corrupt practices since taking possession of the ministry, which has controlled law enforcement and intelligence agencies. But he said that making that information public immediately, or simply throwing open the doors to secret archives, was not in the country's best interest. "Our aim is not big headlines in the paper," Creel said. "It will happen, in time and with a consensus, after bridges are constructed. . . . Our main bet is on the future, not the past." Creel acknowledged that there is a difference of opinion about how to handle the past among Fox's aides, a diverse group that ranges from leftist intellectuals to conservative business leaders. But he said that criticism that the government is not moving fast enough is unfair. "We have to make people accountable but we can't do it in 24 hours or even three or four weeks," he said. He also said the administration was not interested in "revenge or a witch hunt." To clean up Cisen, the government will have to do more than simply turn off the tape recorders. The agency, as with many Mexican law enforcement groups, is widely believed to have been infiltrated by Mexico's powerful organized crime groups. There is widespread suspicion that corrupt officials have sold information gathered by Cisen to kidnappers and drug gangs. Recently, there have been reliable reports of former government officials buying their files from intelligence agents to keep them from surfacing. In addition to Cisen, military intelligence agencies, the police, state and municipal governments and a variety of shadowy spinoff agencies have been involved in taping telephone calls. Aguayo, who is writing a book about the history of intelligence operations in Mexico and was given limited access last year to files of Cisen and its predecessor agencies, was the first outsider to review the files since the 1920s. The scholar said he discovered clear evidence of government involvement in disappearances and killings over the past

COUNTRY: KENYA (96%); ZIMBABWE (94%); AFRICA (94%); UNITED STATES (92%); SOUTH AFRICA (79%)
TEXT: Secretary of State Colin L. Powell met today with Kenya's longtime president, Daniel arap Moi, and urged him to step aside and let a new president be elected next year. That repeated a message General Powell had sent to the president of Zimbabwe earlier on his African tour. General Powell called on Mr. Moi to push through an anti-corruption law in order to re-establish ties with the World Bank and International Monetary Fund; the organizations cut off loans to Kenya four years ago. But Mr. Moi left American officials guessing about his political intentions. Kenyan law calls for elections to be held by December 2002, and Mr. Moi, who is 76 years old and has been in office since 1978, is barred from re-election. Some of his supporters have urged him to change the system and run again, but General Powell suggested he could leave a positive legacy by stepping aside and allowing a new generation to guide the country. After meeting with General Powell today, Mr. Moi spoke cryptically outside the statehouse about General Powell's call for free elections and new leadership. "I think it is too much always trying to undermine the intelligence of the African people," Mr. Moi said dismissively. "Those who will determine the destiny of Kenya or other countries are the people themselves." In a speech at a university in Johannesburg the day before, General Powell voiced his belief that some African leaders had clung to power too long. He cited President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, who has headed that country as either president or prime minister for more than two decades. Kenya has been ruled by the Kenya African National Union since its independence from Britain in 1963 and has become in effect a one-party state. Opposition parties are splintered among the country's many tribal groups, and Mr. Moi has used strong-arm tactics to keep rivals at bay. Tribal rivalries have long been an unsettling factor in Kenya's formation as an independent country. General Powell made a point today of meeting with opposition lawmakers such as Mwai Kibaki, a former vice president to Mr. Moi, who has since formed the rival Democratic Party and is regarded as a leading opposition candidate for president. General Powell was also joined in a discussion by Raila Odinga, son of another former vice president, Oginga Odinga. Raila Odinga had been jailed by Mr. Moi for allegedly organizing an opposition movement to topple the government. Some of Mr. Moi's allies have been keeping alive the idea of a another Moi term, leading to much speculation that the president, the son of a herdsman, will cling to the post. Despite his grip on power, Mr. Moi's official biography portrays him as a reluctant stateman who merely filled a leadership void and rebuffed plotters in 1992 who have tried to interrupt his elected leadership. "Though moves to frustrate and destroy his political career were plotted, he calmly resisted and humbled himself, forgiving those who were after his neck as he assumed power," his biography says. A group of Kenyans also sought to press General Powell during his stay here for more compensation for victims of the 1998 bombing of the American Embassy here, which left 224 Kenyans dead and thousands injured. General Powell placed a wreath at a memorial for victims today but he declined to discuss the matter, saying there were lawsuits pending.  URL: http://www.nytimes.com

COUNTRY: AFRICA (97%); SERBIA (94%); RWANDA (92%); SERBIA & MONTENEGRO (92%); KENYA (92%); NETHERLANDS (88%); SIERRA LEONE (79%); CONGO, THE DEMOCRATIC REPUBLIC OF THE (79%); CHILE (79%); SOMALIA (79%); EUROPE (79%); LIBERIA (79%); BELGIUM (53%); GERMANY (50%)
TEXT: AFRICA is where most of world's warfare is now. Since civilians are often the targets there, it stands to reason that Africa may also be fertile ground in this new era of international justice. So: what signal did the delivery of Slobodan Milosevic to the Hague in exchange for $1.3 billion in assistance to Serbia send to Africa and its often appalling leaders? John Githongo, head of Transparency International in Kenya, an anti-corruption group, believes that the message is mostly a good one for ordinary Africans: that some of their worst leaders may be held to a long-overdue accounting. But that does not stop him from wondering about a new era of confusion and abuse, alongside the hope for greater justice. After all, $1.3 billion is a lot of money -- roughly one-tenth the crippling amount that the continent pays each year to service its debt. What's more, the search for justice for past crimes may provide a way of hiding new ones, or at least major shortcomings in a new regime that may not be much better than the last. Handing over an old leader to The Hague, Mr. Githongo said, "would have an enormous effect on legitimizing the new regime by saying, 'We haven't done very much but the reason we haven't done very much is that the people before us made such a cockup of everything.' It does distract people." Most experts dismiss the possibility that the precedent with Mr. Milosevic and the cash promised to Serbia could create "an export industry in dictators along with diamonds, gold and cobalt," as Richard H. Dicker, director of the international justice program at Human Rights Watch, jokingly put it. But the Milosevic extradition, like that of Augusto Pinochet of Chile, does raise " unique challenges to leadership in Africa," Mr. Githongo said. "And it's only now being discussed." Africa never had a Nuremberg trial, the decisive point at which Europeans defined what was acceptable and what was not. There is a tribunal to try suspects for the genocide in Rwanda, but some experts argue that its effect has been small, in part because the crimes, while horrific, were so local, and because, until recently, it had achieved few convictions. In any event, Africa experts note that for decades during the cold war, all manner of crimes, both military and economic, were overlooked in the name of geostrategic positioning. Thus Mobutu Sese Seko of Zaire, Mohamed Siad Barre of Somalia or Samuel Doe of Liberia essentially got a pass to act as they pleased. All that changed with the end of the cold war, and perhaps more pointedly, as the borders of justice dropped to the point where suspects in the Rwandan genocide in 1994 were tried this year in a Belgian court. But many leaders in Africa were slow to recognize those changes and now, in theory, they face a completely new set of rules from the same people who wrote the older, more lenient ones. That could create complications for the imposers of trans-border justice. "If Mobutu was being taken to court, his lawyers would argue, 'Well, why not the United States government and France and Belgium, who bankrolled him?" asked Salih Booker, executive director of Africa Action, an advocacy group in Washington. "That is the only refuge of African dictators that has some basis in fact." There are some worries that, at least in the short run, the new rules may already be having the effect of prolonging conflict and keeping corrupt leaders in power. In Burundi, for example, ethnic Tutsi leaders have reportedly expressed fear of prosecution for their part in the civil war there, a clear disincentive to leaving office soon. It is analogous to the situation in Kenya, where there have not been questions about crimes against humanity, but where a grant of amnesty on corruption issues has reportedly been put forward as the key to persuading President Daniel arap Moi to end his long rule there. Mr. Githongo argues that for African societies, the international prosecution of former leaders is not yet compatible with more pressing goals. Those societies have a deep need for peace, he said, and focusing narrowly on prosecution now may stir up more immediate conflict. He noted the apparent success of achieving peace in Mozambique after granting some amnesty to end the civil war there a decade ago. "There are other important issues like reconciliation," he said. "Terrible things have been done. Let's go through a transitional process but let's keep a low profile. Let's not be vindictive." His argument also raises the larger question of whether trying war criminals is, in fact, the most pressing need for Africa -- a variation of the argument often heard in Africa that AIDS deserves attention but only as one of many problems. Mr. Booker of Africa Action argues that " justice is almost a necessity for democratic development," but he adds: "At the same time, I would tend to be critical of the conventional human rights community that focus almost entirely on the legalistic approach to justice, to a court-based approach that does not address what may be the greater injustices: denial of access to clean water or to health care or corruption that are the consequences of dictatorial rule." DESPITE the questions, African nations have largely signed on to the idea of a permanent tribunal for crimes against humanity (even as the United States has dragged its feet). And many argue that international justice provides a new set of laws that ordinary Africans can look to, even if their own leaders ignore them in their own lands. "When Milosevic was overthrown, the next day in the Ivory Coast people were demonstrating and citing Serbian democracy as an example," said Harold Hongju Koh, a Yale law professor who served as President Clinton's chief adviser on human rights. "So we know that images and educational lessons are now carried through those channels." This sends the message, he said, that "a page has been turned, that what was tolerated in the past will not be tolerated in the future. And that has the potential to raise both the communal standards and the continental standards."

COUNTRY: AFRICA (98%); CARIBBEAN ISLANDS (93%); CANADA (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%)
TEXT: President Bush will propose today to double spending on a U.S. initiative for education in Africa to $ 200 million over five years and will announce plans to travel to the continent next year, senior administration officials said yesterday. The announcement on African education will be the second, relatively modest foreign assistance plan unveiled within two days by an administration that has questioned whether such aid has been wasted on inefficient and corrupt governments. Yesterday, Bush pledged an additional $ 500 million over three years to help prevent HIV-infected mothers in parts of Africa and the Caribbean from transmitting the virus, which causes AIDS, to their infants. "Medical science gives us the power to save these young lives. Conscience demands that we do so," the president declared in a Rose Garden ceremony. The flurry of initiatives come as Bush prepares to head next week to a summit of leaders from the Group of Eight leading industrial nations in Canada, where Africa will be a major focus. The $ 10 billion U.S. foreign aid budget is the lowest among rich countries as a percentage of economic output, and the new proposals could help the administration project a compassionate image at the summit. Most of the 20 million deaths from AIDS have occurred in sub-Saharan Africa, where HIV infection rates are the highest in the world. The United Nations estimates that 800,000 children were born last year infected with the virus, even though as little as a single dose of medication to mother and child at birth can prevent transmission up to half the time. Bush's initiative aims to prevent up to 146,000 infant infections over the next five years. It is projected to provide extended treatment with life-extending anti-retroviral drugs for infected infants and their parents in numbers that will increase as the program expands. But while saying the proposals were welcome, activists, aid advocates and some in Congress criticized them as too little, too late. The AIDS initiative focused on the least politically sensitive aspect of care and treatment for a disease that is most often transmitted through adult sexual activity. "By choosing to focus primarily on 'innocent' newborns," said the Global Alliance of activist groups, "Bush is leaving women, families and communities for dead." There was also criticism of the size of the funding, and what some saw as an attempt to take credit for congressional initiatives they believed Bush had helped undermine. Sen. Richard J. Durbin (D-Ill.), who along with Sen. Arlen Specter (R-Pa.) had proposed $ 700 million in new spending this year on global AIDS programs, yesterday called the Bush plan a "shell game," saying it "provides no funding beyond that already provided by the Senate until the year 2004." Bush's $ 500 million consists of $ 200 million the House and Senate have already added to the president's proposed emergency terrorism appropriation for this year, which administration officials said would be spent over this year and next, and $ 300 million that Bush said he would put in his fiscal 2004 budget request next year. This year's budget for global AIDS projects is about $ 1 billion, without the new funding. Rock star Bono, a global development advocate who last month accompanied Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill on a 10-day tour of Africa, issued a statement saying: "This crisis urgently demands an historic presidential AIDS initiative. This isn't it, but could be the beginning of it." Others in Congress and among nongovernmental organizations said they were glad to have what Bush proposed. Rep. Jim Kolbe (R-Ariz.), who shepherded the House's version of the $ 200 million in emergency funds, said he was "especially pleased" by Bush's initiative. Mark Isaac, public policy director at the Elizabeth Glaser Pediatric AIDS Foundation, called it "real leadership . . . in fighting global AIDS." Isaac said that working with mothers who care more about helping their children than avoiding the stigma often associated with AIDS in the developing world often provided a way to expand prevention and treatment. Paul De Lay, director of the HIV/AIDS office at the U.S. Agency for International Development, said that infants infected even after treatment with nevirapine, the drug used to reduce transmission rates from mothers, would be put on a permanent regime of anti-retroviral drugs, along with those infected mothers and fathers whose stage of disease qualifies them for treatment. The program is initially targeted at eight African countries, to expand to 12 by 2004, plus Guyana and Haiti and a regional program for other Caribbean islands. The plan also includes improvements in health care infrastructure, an exchange program between U.S. and African and Caribbean hospitals and initiatives to provide African women alternatives to breast feeding, which can pass the disease. The education proposal is both an increase in size and a fleshing out of specifics for an initiative that Bush unveiled last year. Administration officials said the money will go to train 420,000 teachers, provide 250,000 scholarships for girls, and provide 4.5 million more textbooks for African schoolchildren. But the level of funding drew a negative reaction from aid advocates. The world's rich nations are being exhorted by the World Bank and other aid agencies to contribute billions of dollars a year to fund an initiative aimed at ensuring that all children in poor countries finish at least five years of schooling by 2015; currently, more than 100 million elementary-school-age children are not in class at all. The United States and other donor nations have backed the plan in principle but not all have been forthcoming with the money. "I think it's disappointing that the president is thinking on such a small scale when the needs are so great," said John Ruthrauff, senior policy adviser at Oxfam America, citing estimates that $ 5 billion a year would be required to meet the U.N.-backed goal of achieving universal primary education by 2015. Administration officials countered by emphasizing the importance of Bush's plans to visit Africa. Noting that Bush earlier this year proposed a 50 percent increase in U.S. foreign aid spending targeted at countries that adopt anti-corruption and free market policies, they asserted that the amount of money is much less important than Bush's demonstrated commitment to African development. "As the president said today, as the [AIDS] initiative demonstrates success, we will provide more resources to it," one senior official said. "That is this administration's approach -- instead of 'more money, more money, more money,' we're saying, 'more results, more results, more results,' and money will follow results."

COUNTRY: AFRICA (99%); UNITED STATES (95%); CANADA (94%); ZIMBABWE (93%); SOUTH AFRICA (92%); JAPAN (51%)
TEXT: THE LEADERS of the leading countries gather in Canada today and tomorrow to talk, among other things, about helping Africa. But the three main channels of assistance that they will discuss are each cluttered with obstacles. The first channel is the "African Renaissance" plan put forward by South Africa's President Thabo Mbeki and other African leaders. This commits the continent to democracy, the rule of law and anti-corruption efforts; the hope is that good governance will be rewarded by inflows of fresh capital. It's a good plan in theory and is welcome in that it's written by Africans rather than outsiders. But it isn't credible. Mr. Mbeki has had a chance to put into practice his pro-democracy sentiments by pressuring his neighbor, President Robert Mugabe of Zimbabwe, into respecting political, human and economic rights. But Mr. Mbeki has failed to intervene effectively while Zimbabwe's leader has stolen an election, tortured hundreds of opponents and expropriated private farms. Until Mr. Mbeki and other African leaders get serious about isolating Mr. Mugabe, it will be difficult to take the African Renaissance plan seriously. The second channel is an initiative to expand primary-school enrollment in poor countries. Two years ago the rich governments represented at the Canada summit promised to back developing nations that came forward with sound education policies. The World Bank, acting in consultation with donor governments, has reviewed a large number of proposals and judged 18 of them sound. But although the Bush administration deserves credit for keeping this initiative alive over the past 18 months, it appears disinclined to back it with cash. Other donor countries may prove more generous. But if the United States remains on the sidelines, an effort to help Africa that has taken two years to develop may now lose momentum. The third potential channel for helping Africa is trade. Last November the Bush administration helped to launch a new round of trade talks and gave it a pro-Africa twist: This new "Development Round" would focus on things that matter to Africans, such as cutting barriers to farm exports. But the administration then broke its halo by signing on to the huge jump in subsidies for domestic farmers -- subsidies that will boost production in the United States, so squeezing out exports from poor countries. The Japanese and Europeans practice outragreous farm protection too. But reformers in Brussels and Tokyo are having a hard time arguing for more open farm trade now that the United States has marched off in the opposite direction. Unfortunately, therefore, the summit in Canada is unlikely to help Africa much, though we'd be delighted to be proven wrong. Meanwhile in Washington, there is something that could make a difference. Congress needs to revive presidential trade promotion authority, which has passed both chambers but which has yet to go to conference. The chief obstacle is the refusal of Rep. Bill Thomas (R-Calif.), chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, to accept reasonable Democratic proposals to help workers who lose jobs as a result of trade. Unless Mr. Thomas relents, he may lack the votes to get the trade measure through the House after the conference negotiations. The midterm elections are approaching, and time is running out. Mr. Thomas, a smart champion of trade, should not let his views on unemployment insurance become yet another obstacle to Africa's advancement.

When Mwai Kibaki was injured in a car accident this month, he didn't seek treatment at his local hospital. He went to the airport and boarded a flight to London. Kibaki's injuries were relatively straightforward -- a broken arm and a sprained ankle -- but Kenyan hospitals just don't provide the level of medical care he wanted. His decision to go abroad was hardly unusual. Kenyans and foreigners who can afford to do so frequently travel to developed countries for health care. But Kibaki, 71, attracted more attention than most. He was running for president of Kenya, and his evacuation to Britain in the thick of the campaign was a stinging reminder of the painful lack of basic services in this East African nation of 30 million people. "It's sad really," said Meshach Onguti, the new director of Kenyatta National Hospital, where overcrowding forces two and three patients to share a bed, and technology in the emergency room dates from around the late 1970s. "Kibaki's decision to leave his own country for medical care, well, it's just this huge metaphor for the state of every service in this country." Kenyan voters went to the polls on Friday for a watershed election that will end the 24-year rule of the loved, hated and omnipresent President Daniel arap Moi, who is barred under the constitution from running again. Partial results indicate that Kibaki's trip to London didn't hurt his candidacy a bit; the opposition leader appears headed for a landslide victory. If Kibaki indeed wins, he will inherit a seemingly endless list of problems to solve: not just inadequate health care, but a scarcity of jobs, a public education system in shambles and a shattered infrastructure of rocky roads, sporadic electricity and balky telephones. Some Kenyans wonder where he should begin; others say the answer is simple: End corruption. Nothing is blamed more frequently for the country's woes than rampant corruption and patronage. Kenyan political analysts say corruption is woven through every element of a society that has come to accept the inevitability of giving or getting "a little something" to get through each day. Kenyans regularly speak of being unable to get a job, proper hospital care, a driver's license, phone lines and even a chance to pay bills unless they bribe someone. "Corruption is the key, really," said John Githongo local head of Transparency International, a corruption watchdog group with a special office in Nairobi. "I mean, this country collects billions in taxes each year. And if you look at what the government does with it, it's not very much. "We have in Kenya impunity towards corruption. Rwandans know genocide; we know corruption. And it has hurt us and held us back." Under Moi, critics say, a system of patronage developed that favored a small percentage of the population -- police to teachers to the distant cousins of government ministers -- and provided nothing for the vast majority of Kenyans. For example, some blame the terrorist attacks on the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi in 1998 and the Paradise Hotel in Mombasa last month on the fact that weapons can easily be smuggled into the country with a bribe. When phones don't work, the electricity goes out and roads become wracked with deep potholes, it is often the funds that are meant to maintain these services that get pocketed. It often takes a bribe to get a job or run a business. "I tried to get a job. At one point I attempted to sell eggs. It all collapsed," said James Maato, 26, who has been unemployed for five years and sat listlessly at a city park one day recently. "There was too much corruption. I couldn't get anything done. I had to hand out a bit of money, and I didn't have enough." While few Kenyans question the importance of rooting out corruption, some are unsure if either Kibaki or his principal opponent, ruling party candidate Uhuru Kenyatta, is capable of doing it. "They are going to have to clean up a big mess," said Sammy Wambua, a political analyst for the East African Standard, a major newspaper here. "There [are] a lot of [people] at every level who will be working against them. It may take a very, very long time and a lot of desire to really do it." Nevertheless, whoever wins will be under intense international pressure to commit to tackling the issue. Such international agencies as the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are withholding hundreds of millions of dollars earmarked for Kenya until corruption is reined in. When the IMF suspended a $ 220 million loan in 1997, it said it was doing so because of "absurd and arguably unnecessary donor rituals." Leaders of Kibaki's National Rainbow Coalition have announced plans to form a national forgiveness and reconciliation team that would offer anyone charged with stealing money from the government a chance to avoid prosecution by giving the money back. They also said they would begin forming committees to combat corruption and patronage in the police department and the court system. "Jobs will be given on merit," said Raila Odinga, an opposition leader. "Jobs will no longer be given on the basis of someone's tribe or where they come from." Kibaki has also said that if he wins the election, he will publicly declare his wealth -- something that Moi has never done. Watchdog groups have said Kibaki's idea could set a new tone toward stopping corruption in everyday life. The election campaign offered little hope, however, as candidates continued the practice of handing out money for what Kenyans commonly call "our daily bread." In the rural village of Mbeere, in the impoverished eastern section of the country, Kenyatta's sister gave out "tea" -- the euphemism for a bribe on Christmas Day. Families lined up for the equivalent of $ 2.50, in a country where most people live on a dollar a day. In response, the Daily Nation newspaper ran an editorial that warned Kenyans: "Don't vote with your stomachs." At Kenyatta National Hospital, examples of how corruption hurts every level of the institution's functions can be seen at every turn. Onguti, the new director, said he had to fire much of the staff for inefficiency and corruption. At the same time, the IMF has withheld health care funding since 2000 until the moribund Kenya anti-corruption authority resumes work. Both presidential candidates have said they would restore that unit. The hospital's bathrooms are dirty, with urine-stained floors and feces smeared across toilets, and nurses said they were told to pay for cleaning supplies with their own money. There is no MRI machine, and cancer patients have to wait three months or more for treatment because there isn't enough equipment. Conditions at other medical centers throughout the country are worse. In a country where 700 people die every day of an HIV-related illness, an HIV/AIDS clinic in Mombasa has only headache medicine and rubbing alcohol. "The problem is, shall we say, misappropriation of funds and a lack of international money," said Ewoi Benguwn, a doctor at the Fatima Medical Clinic as she handed an aspirin to an AIDS patient. "I mean, honestly, most doctors who work here won't get medical treatment in this country." Editorial assistant Candice Miranda contributed to this report.

COUNTRY: KENYA (99%); AFRICA (92%); SUDAN (79%); ZAMBIA (79%); SOMALIA (79%); UNITED STATES (79%); EUROPEAN UNION MEMBER STATES (71%)
TEXT: Kenyan opposition leader Mwai Kibaki won the job of president today in a historic and peaceful vote heralded as this nation's first step toward ending authoritarian rule. It was a day of celebrations, with Kenyans dancing in the streets of the capital, Nairobi, and riding on trucks and waving branches -- a symbol of a new start -- as results showed that the four-decade dominance of President Daniel arap Moi's party had ended. "This marks history," said Kibaki, wearing a brightly colored shirt and sitting in the garden of his posh home in Nairobi. "This for me is a great job, and Kenyans have given me a great challenge." Kibaki, 71, will be sworn in Monday as Kenya's third president since independence from Britain in 1963. He defeated Uhuru Kenyatta, 41, son of Kenya's venerated nationalist and first president, Jomo Kenyatta, and Moi's chosen protege. Kenyatta conceded defeat hours before the election results were released, saying: "I accept the choice of the people that Kibaki will be the third president of this country. From those ashes a strong foundation will begin again." Kibaki, an economist who has run for president twice before, promised to fight corruption in a nation where a system of patronage and bribes has damaged and depleted state institutions. The country ranks as one of the most corrupt in the world, according to watchdog groups. "First and foremost we should start by tackling corruption," Kibaki said, adding that he and his top officials would release documents detailing their wealth when they take office. The smooth election defied widespread fears that it would be rigged, as voting was in 1992 and 1997. Election observers from the European Union and the Carter Center in the United States said the election sends an important message to other African nations, where transitions are often fragile and frequently lead to civil wars. "This has a great bearing on Africa where there are neighboring countries suffering lack of peace in Somalia, Sudan and Congo," said Kenneth Kaunda, the former president of Zambia, who ran an election monitoring team. Kaunda was voted out of office in 1991 and retired peacefully. "Kenyans have given us a good lesson which we must emulate." The Electoral Commission of Kenya declared Kibaki and his National Rainbow Coalition the winner with 63 percent of the vote over Kenyatta's 30 percent. With results for 192 seats reported in the 210-seat legislature, the Rainbow alliance captured 122; Kenyatta's party, Kenya African National Union (KANU), won 52. Smaller parties won the remaining places. But the new political leaders face deep challenges. Many of the people in Kibaki's coalition defected just two months ago from Moi's party. Kibaki himself was Moi's vice president from 1978 to 1988 and was also the country's longest-serving finance minister, holding the post from 1969 to 1982. Some wonder if Kibaki's party -- hastily assembled primarily to fight Moi -- can stick together and enforce real change. Moi has ruled Kenya since 1978 and the system, analysts said, needs to be completely restructured.  But Kibaki's anti-corruption plans could lead to tension. "There are no angels in parliament," said John Githongo, head of the Nairobi branch of Transparency International, a corruption watchdog group. "There is a lot of euphoria right now. But civil society and vigilance cannot stop." During Moi's rule, taking bribes and paying off government workers to obtain even small services such as parking became a daily part of life in Kenya. And Moi became larger than life: His picture is on the country's currency and hangs from the wall of nearly every store. Streets, schools and airports are named after him. And he instituted a national holiday: Moi Day. Kibaki said he is sincere about ending the government's authoritarian style and that governing "is not a matter of promoting the ego of a president." "I think a president should prove himself by things that he does and if he changes the life of ordinary Kenyans then after he dies people can memorialize him, but not on every street and airport and nightclub." The U.S. ambassador, Johnnie Carson, called the election "historic for Africa." "What is happening here is an example of what can be done in other countries," Carson said. "And it's extraordinarily important." President Bush said he is looking forward to working with Kibaki. White House spokesman Scott McClellan said Bush also welcomed the fact that the elections were peaceful. "The people of Kenya have chosen a new leader and all parties have acted responsibly in working to institutionalize democracy in Kenya," McClellan said. The elections have also brought enormous hope to Kenyans -- many of whom survive on $ 1 a day and live without electricity and running water. Bernard Ngoroge, 32, took his children to city hall to witness the change of power. "This is Kenyan history," said Ngoroge, watching the crowds cheering and dancing in the streets. "I want them to see this and remember that this is a very joyful day for Kenyans." Many Kenyans said they hoped they would no longer have to pay bribes now that Moi was gone. Crowds took to Moi Avenue outside of city hall and sang to police officers in Swahili, "No More Kitu Kidogo," a phrase meaning "a little something." "We have wandered in the desert for 40 years of KANU, and for 40 years Kenyans have suffered," said Milka Opondo, 38, a mother of two. "Now we are free. Now we have a real democracy."

Few presidents have started their terms with higher public expectations than Mwai Kibaki, elected on Saturday and inaugurated yesterday as president of a jubilant and startled Kenya. Kenyans are coming to terms with the fact that their autocratic leader, Daniel arap Moi, has allowed a free election, saw his chosen successor defeated and permitted the challenger to take office. For this Mr. Moi deserves credit -- but for little else. He is one of Africa's Big Men, who put his face on the currency and demanded songs of praise from his people. In 24 years in power he has presided over exploding corruption, promoted tribal division, permitted economic decline and corroded democratic institutions. Mr. Moi has left behind many more problems than President Kibaki will be able to solve. But if he chooses his battles wisely -- and from early comments, it seems he has -- Mr. Kibaki, a respected economist considered uncorrupted, can do much to rebuild Kenya. Kenya will be a much happier place if Mr. Kibaki simply refrains from Mr. Moi's mischief, such as fomenting ethnic violence and persecuting the opposition. Presidents rarely seek to reduce their powers, but Mr. Kibaki should be the exception. A well-regarded commission will soon release ideas for reform, likely to include reducing presidential powers. Mr. Kibaki should follow the recommendations. Mr. Kibaki has rightly made eliminating fees for primary school and improving health care his top projects. Combating corruption, the reform perhaps most desired by Kenyans, is his other priority. Kenyans pay a bribe every two days, according to a recent survey. This has driven away foreign investment. Nearly $1 billion in international aid has been frozen because the country failed to pass anti-corruption legislation and because Mr. Moi obstructed the work of anti-corruption commissions. While fighting corruption is notoriously difficult, Mr. Kibaki can set a new tone. His announcement that his ministers will have to declare their wealth is a good, if largely symbolic, start. Because Mr. Moi's machinery is still very much in power, the new president is fudging the question of how to treat past crimes. Mr. Kibaki could investigate tribal clashes that killed hundreds of people, apparently with the complicity of high-level government officials. Prosecutions might be relatively safe because Mr. Moi ordered the first inquiry, though he kept the results secret for years. Mr. Kibaki might also be able to prosecute the players in Kenya's most notorious corruption scandal, who could possibly include Mr. Moi. The new president may be tempted to reward his predecessor for holding elections, but he should not be. Serious crimes were committed by members of the Moi government. Justice, at least for the worst of them, is part of restoring the rule of law to Kenya.

Once upon a time, World Bank financiers viewed their mission in narrow terms: Lend money to poor countries to try to make them richer. The governments that borrowed the money might let a bribe determine who was awarded a contract, and money intended for new highways or hospitals was sometimes siphoned off for other purposes, such as buying weapons. But overall, bank officials said, a little bit of corruption was tolerable -- often necessary -- to make economic development work. They don't say that anymore. Responding to evidence that corruption impedes the progress of failing economies, the World Bank in the late 1990s began cracking down on the corrupt practices of its borrowers. "The one thing I'm proudest of is our work on corruption," bank President James D. Wolfensohn said recently. Before he took office in 1995, Wolfensohn said, the bank considered corruption "an issue of politics," as opposed to one of economic development. Now, "it is now central to what we do." Under Wolfensohn, the bank began participating in international efforts to fight corruption. It developed internal controls to audit its projects. It compiled a blacklist of nearly 100 companies and individuals banned from receiving bank-funded contracts because of bribery, theft or for breaking other rules. Since 1996, the bank has started more than 600 anti-corruption programs in nearly 100 countries, according to a published statement. Some observers of the World Bank -- which reported that it lent $ 19.5 billion of dollars in the year ended June 30, 2002 -- say it should be doing more to discourage the governments and companies it works with from misusing its money, which comes mostly from the governments of rich countries. The bank has continued to fund projects in countries where corruption is said to be rampant, such as Bangladesh. Only one country, Kenya, has been prohibited from receiving bank loans because of its government's corrupt practices, and that was temporary. Despite the blacklist, the bank sometimes has been reluctant to ban companies that violate its rules. Because many of the world's most corrupt countries are also among the poorest, the bank's new stance can force difficult choices between continuing aid to a country that needs it and cutting it to discourage corruption. Poor countries are also notoriously poor record-keepers, making auditing more difficult. "No one says this is easy. It's a trade-off," said Peter Eigen, founder and president of Transparency International, a corruption watchdog group. "You can't just have a simplistic link between the level of corruption and the level of funding. Some of these countries would really struggle without the bank's loans." Eigen, who left the World Bank in 1991 when his pleas for a stronger anti-corruption stance were ignored, said he believes that under Wolfensohn the bank has made fighting corruption a priority. "It's very hard to change a large organization like the World Bank, and they're still working through this," Eigen said. "They were pretty bad, and allowed [corruption] to become a major problem. There's been a total change in policy, but to change from policy to total implementation is a long way to go. While I'd be hard pressed to say they've licked it, they are an enthusiastic and effective partner." The U.S. General Accounting Office evaluated the bank's anti-corruption efforts and gave a mixed review in a June report. While it found that the bank had taken "important steps" toward reducing internal corruption, the agency also recommended further action, including a more extensive audit of whether the bank's loans are used for their intended purposes. The bank "has a long way to go," said William Easterly, an economics professor at New York University. "If the client is important enough geostrategically or one they want to cultivate in the long run, they will continue lending to them, despite long histories of corruption. They continue forcing loans down that pipe." Corruption can take many forms, but it is usually defined as the misuse of public office or money for private gain. In the 1980s and early 1990s, most academic literature on economic development argued that corruption could help "grease the wheels" of a fledgling economy. But after several studies showed that corruption impedes development, many foreign aid programs began advocating "zero tolerance" toward corruption. The World Bank responded to the shifting conventional wisdom. Soon after Wolfensohn railed against the "cancer of corruption" at the bank's 1996 annual meeting in Hong Kong, the bank formed an investigative body to audit its loans and set up a 24-hour hotline to allow staff and members of the public to report allegations of corruption. In November 1998 the bank convened a "sanctions committee" to punish companies and individuals guilty of corruption. In 2000 it formed a "department of institutional integrity" to investigate allegations of corruption within the bank or in connection with bank-funded contracts. It also started working with anti-corruption groups that once were highly critical of its activities. With Transparency International, the bank supports anti-corruption efforts such as an initiative to better account for money lent to countries involved in military conflicts. To combat corruption, the bank can ban, or "debar," companies that use bribes and other unethical means to secure contracts, or it can directly punish governments by denying or decreasing loans to those where corruption is rampant. World Bank officials cited a recent audit of an urban development project in Sulawesi, Indonesia, as an example of a successful crackdown on companies. A 2002 review of the project -- for which the bank provided money to improve water services, housing, sanitation, flood control, roads and transportation on the remote Indonesian island -- found widespread corruption in procurement. In April of this year, the bank debarred 15 Indonesian companies for various lengths of time. The bank has permanently debarred 93 companies, but provides no information about them beyond their names and where they are based. The list includes four local firms. Asia Construction, which the blacklist says is located in Delaware and Maryland, is out of business. Two other companies, Digidata and Knowledge Engineering, both of Virginia, are owned by David Riper, of Fairfax, whose name also appears on the bank's blacklist. He was accused of paying a kickback to a bank official to help secure a contract on a project in Nairobi. Riper declined a request for comment. One Washington company, International Access Corp., is debarred until 2004. An attorney for the company said in a prepared statement that the firm "was not treated fairly" by the bank but did not address the reasons for the bank's decision. Despite the lengthy list of banned companies, several critics say that simply targeting firms that don't follow the rules is not enough. "The view of most economists is that all the money is really going into one pot," Easterly said. "The government might refrain from stealing funds on a World Bank project, but compensate by stealing more from another project." Instead, Easterly advocates cutting off countries whose governments have demonstrable corruption problems. In June, the bank announced that Kenya, an East African country making a difficult transition to democracy after decades of one-party rule, was approved for a new loan of more than $ 100 million. In the past decade, Kenya has temporarily been cut off from funding by the World Bank and its affiliate lending organization, the International Monetary Fund, because of widespread political corruption. As recently as May, a government official there was accused of taking a $ 100,000 bribe from a contractor in the Kenya Urban Transport Initiative Program, a bank project that was suspended in August 2002 because of charges of rampant bribery and embezzlement. In approving the recent loan, the bank cited several steps Kenya's new government took to combat corruption. Meanwhile, the bank continues to increase its lending to Bangladesh, a poor and densely populated South Asian country plagued by debilitating floods, which consistently ranks near the top of world corruption surveys. It is due to receive $ 554 million from the World Bank this year, and roughly the same amount next year, said Enrique Pantoja, a World Bank country officer for Bangladesh. The country's loan package for the previous three years averaged around $ 250 million a year, he said. "Not all poor countries are equally corrupt," Easterly said. "Why can't they do better at lending to those that do better?" Other development experts point out that the level of corruption in a country is difficult to define and to quantify. Transparency International's index, which ranked Bangladesh as the most corrupt country in the world for 2002, measures the international community's "perception" of corrupt practices, which some say can be misleading. "Bangladesh is actually a tricky case," said Steven Radelet, a senior fellow at the Center for Global Development. "The Transparency number has a few asterisks.
