It leads to a massive misallocation and waste of scarce public-sector budget resources, especially in poor countries, and so has dire human rights consequences -- in many countries palaces and sports stadiums are built while the rural and urban poor do not even have minimal health care and school facilities. It renders foreign aid programs ineffective. European and Japanese multinational corporations routinely pay bribes around the globe. After effective public criticism of its environmental and human rights policies, the Royal Dutch Shell group recently announced a new set of corporate values. But Shell avoided the bribery issue, perhaps because a lot of its business is in Nigeria, which is widely seen by business as the world's most corrupt country. Other leading European multinationals are just as shy as Shell. And no wonder, given the lack of evidence of sincere interest by European leaders in tackling the issue. The United States has done all the work, constantly pushing in the OECD and other forums and stressing that transparency in international contracting is vital. Strong anti-corruption statements by top ministers from other leading industrial nations have been noticeably absent. The new understandings on a treaty are a victory for the U.S. administration and worth applauding. But there is merit in striving now to cement the gains and keep the feet of OECD governments to the fire on this hot issue. Accordingly, the subject of international bribery should be on the agenda of the Group of 7 summit in Denver next month. President Clinton should put it on the agenda and secure some advance support for it. Calls by the president to the heads of the British and Canadian governments could just possibly win their support for a bold Denver declaration. British Prime Minister Tony Blair has, after all, started talking about giving U.K. foreign policy a humanitarian element. The U.S. needs allies in its campaign to curb corruption. Without them the leading Europeans and the Japanese are likely to continue their pro-bribery policies. The writer is vice chairman of Transparency International, a Berlin-based organization seeking to curb corruption in international business transactions.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (93%); MIDDLE EAST (92%); IRAQ (92%); NIGERIA (79%)
TEXT: It's easy to want democracy for the Middle East. But what sort of democracy? Should American foreign policy focus on promoting elections, or on checks and balances? Is the crucial question how power is achieved? Or is it how power is exercised? Paul Collier and Anke Hoeffler, two economists at Oxford University, address these questions in a new paper on oil-rich democracies. Their answer, rooted in statistical analysis of oil states' performance since 1970 under various types of political systems, is that the tendency to focus on elections is correct in most societies but misguided in oil states. In a country such as Iraq, the United States and its allies should care at least as much about the quality of Iraq's judiciary and media as about the quality of its voting. Collier and Hoeffler are actually nicer about elections than most development economists are. Until the 1990s the research consensus held that voting was bad for economic growth, a finding that fitted with the idea that dictators are better at imposing necessary austerity. In the past decade or so, researchers have generally found that elections are more or less growth-neutral. But by taking countries with natural resources out of the sample, Collier and Hoeffler show that ordinary, resource-poor nations grow faster if they have elections. In oil states, however, the opposite holds true -- at least if elections are held in the absence of checks and balances. In countries where natural-resource profits come to a fifth of GDP, the switch from autocracy to electoral competition lowers the annual growth rate by a hefty 2.1 percentage points. Unless there are checks and balances, elections cause oil-rich countries to invest less than they should  --  and to invest badly. As a result they fail to create the public infrastructure that makes growth possible. Why might elections promote growth in most countries but cause underinvestment in oil states? In ordinary countries, where the state has limited cash at its disposal, the most efficient way to attract votes is to provide public goods: low inflation, rule of law, infrastructure that's carefully chosen to benefit the whole society. So elections promote pro-growth policies. In petro-states, by contrast, the simplest way to attract votes is to buy them. Politicians can do that by subsidizing food or handing out government jobs in exchange for loyalty, bribes that promote consumption at the expense of investment. Or they can blow money on projects whose real purpose is to generate kickbacks, so what little investment there is tends to be junky. A good example is Nigeria, which has yo-yoed between military dictatorship and corrupt democracy. In 1978 a new elected government came to power and canceled a $120 million dam contract that had been awarded by the outgoing military dictatorship. A new contract was awarded, but this time it was so padded with kickbacks that it cost an astonishing $600 million. Politicians had spent a fortune getting elected and now needed repayment. Nigeria's more recent transition to democracy, in 1999, at first seemed little better  --  a fact more recently underlined by the anti-corruption drive launched by the democratic president. By the simple expedient of requiring competitive bidding for government contracts, and by checking bid prices against prices for comparable projects posted on the Internet, Nigeria has cut the cost of public-works projects by 40 percent, saving about $2 billion since 2003. Last year the minister for public service reform abolished his own department: He had examined its 25,000-strong payroll and found 5,000 "ghosts" -- workers who drew salaries without ever coming to the office. So oil-rich societies need to couple elections with checks on elected authorities, as Nigeria is now attempting. This isn't true of ordinary countries; Collier and Hoeffler find that checks and balances in resource-poor countries tend to reduce growth, perhaps because they create gridlock in place of necessary public action. But in oil-rich societies a freedom of information act, an independent public prosecutor, and some separation of power over the public purse are essential to counteract incentives for corruption. This conclusion needs to register with the Bush administration. It's natural to defer to Iraqi leaders as they write their constitution this year; after all, it's their country. But the political class in any nation has few incentives to create checks on its own freedom to govern, and elections, which take place only occasionally and attract lots of healthy international attention, are easier to get right than the boring details of competitive tendering. Left to its own devices, Iraq is likely to fall into the trap that Collier and Hoeffler describe --  a constitution that focuses adequately on how power is achieved but too little on how it is exercised. mallabys@washpost.com

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); GERMANY (92%); EUROPE (92%); SOUTHERN EUROPE (90%); AFRICA (79%); CENTRAL EUROPE (58%)
TEXT: DaimlerChrysler AG's disclosure last week that the Department of Justice is investigating bribery allegations involving the car company's European executives is a sign of the U.S. government's stepped-up anti-corruption efforts targeting both domestic and non-U.S. companies, according to legal experts in the field. "There's definitely been a substantial increase in these cases," said Raymond Banoun, head of Cadwalader, Wickersham & Taft LLC's business fraud practice. "And it's non-U.S. companies that are being investigated. There's loads of these cases right now." In a July 28 Securities and Exchange Commission filing, the German carmaker said the Justice Department had joined an SEC investigation begun last year into possible violations of the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, which bars U.S. companies from paying bribes abroad. The company said it is conducting its own investigation of "payments from certain accounts" that may have violated the law. A source familiar with the internal investigation said that the company made payments to government officials in Africa but that the company has not determined whether the payments were illegal. The source spoke on the condition of anonymity because of the continuing investigation. A spokesman for DaimlerChrysler declined to comment on the investigation. The probe grew out of a civil case filed last year by a former company accountant. The former employee charged in his wrongful-dismissal suit that senior DaimlerChrysler officials were aware of secret accounts used to bribe foreign officials but did nothing to stop the practice. The accountant, who worked for the company's Chrysler operation in Michigan, settled with DaimlerChrysler this year. Though DaimlerChrysler is based in Germany, it lists its stock on the New York Stock Exchange and is subject to anti-bribery laws here. The SEC, which pioneered the anti-bribery investigations in the 1970s that led to FCPA's passage in 1977, often plays a main role in many anti-bribery investigations. In a 1999 compact with the United States, European nations agreed to enact their own anti-bribery laws. Before then, bribery of officials in developing countries was common and considered a business expense. But European prosecutions of bribery allegations of companies there have been slow in coming, said Matt T. Morley, chairman of the corporate department and a managing partner of Fried, Frank, Harris, Shriver & Jacobson LLC's Washington office. "The acid test is still to come" in Europe, he said. "Just because laws are on the books there doesn't mean they will be enforced. You haven't seen a tidal wave of cases in those countries." Both Morley and Banoun said the Department of Justice has aggressively pursued new cases since the 1999 compact gave it expanded jurisdiction over foreign companies with a significant presence in the United States. Morley added that the Justice Department and the SEC have done these types of investigations for decades and are good at it. "The U.S. is trying to show some leadership, so you're seeing them being very aggressive in enforcing the FCPA." In another FCPA investigation, this one tied to Riggs Bank, New York oil company Amerada Hess Corp. disclosed yesterday that the SEC had upgraded its previously informal inquiry into Amerada's payments to the government and officials of Equatorial Guinea. The oil-rich West African country had oil payments routed to its account at Riggs Bank. Riggs's management of those accounts was a key factor in the D.C. bank's guilty plea and $16 million fine in January for failing to prevent possible money laundering. An Amerada Hess spokesperson could not be reached for comment. Other U.S. companies that have said they are being investigated for possible FCPA violations in Equatorial Guinea are Marathon Oil Corp. and ChevronTexaco Corp. A Senate investigative report last year detailed how many business deals and charitable activities the companies did in Equatorial Guinea benefited the country's ruling family. Equatorial Guinea is among the poorest countries in the world, and human rights organizations say its government is among the most repressive and corrupt in Africa.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (94%); KENYA (94%); TOGO (93%); AFRICA (93%); ZIMBABWE (92%); DENMARK (92%); WESTERN AFRICA (92%); GEORGIA (87%); NORTHERN IRELAND (79%); UNITED KINGDOM (79%); EUROPE (79%)
TEXT: NAIROBI -- The United States is suspending $2.5 million in funding for anti-corruption work in Kenya, U.S. Ambassador William Bellamy said Tuesday, citing what he called President Mwai Kibaki's faltering commitment to fighting graft. Bellamy's announcement came one day after a presidential anti-corruption adviser, John Githongo, resigned because he was frustrated with the government's efforts at dealing with corruption. Fighting corruption needs more than a few "honest and exemplary" public servants who are no match "for an executive branch of government in whose ranks the kingpins of corruption operate," Bellamy told the British Business Association during a luncheon. Githongo's resignation "sounds the death knell" on the government's fight against corruption, Kenyan human rights activists and business leaders said in a statement. *  TBILISI, Georgia -- Georgia's president nominated his finance minister as the new head of government, nearly a week after the death of Prime Minister Zurab Zhvaniya from carbon-monoxide poisoning. President Mikheil Saakashvili picked Zurab Nogaideli, 40, as prime minister after days of consultations with aides and cabinet officials, a spokeswoman said. Parliament has 10 days to approve or reject the nomination, but could vote as soon as Thursday. *  COPENHAGEN -- Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen's center-right government won a second term as Denmark voters embraced plans to keep immigration in check and taxes from rising. With nearly all 4 million ballots tallied, the governing bloc of Liberals, Conservatives and the anti-immigration Danish Peoples Party had 55 percent, giving it 96 seats in the 179-seat parliament. *  BELFAST -- Police charged a 34-year-old man with involvement in the 1998 car bombing in Omagh that killed 29 people, Northern Ireland's deadliest terrorist attack. Police arrested the suspect in the border town of Newry and charged him with stealing the car that was used by IRA dissidents in the bombing. Police withheld his name pending his formal court arraignment Wednesday. He is the third person to face charges stemming from the attack in which the dissident group, calling itself the Real IRA, asserted responsibility. *  LOME, Togo -- The African Union threatened sanctions against Togo as opposition grew to the army's installation of the son of the West African nation's longtime leader as president. The United States endorsed a call by the African Union and the Economic Community of West African States to bring about a peaceful resolution in Togo that "will lead to free and fair elections to select a new president." A general strike closed markets, schools and businesses in southern parts of the capital. *  HARARE, Zimbabwe -- A top official in Zimbabwe's ruling party denounced Archbishop Desmond Tutu, a Nobel peace laureate from South Africa, saying his criticisms of the government played into the hands of white racists. Zimbabwe's leaders have been widely accused of rigging elections and using violence against the opposition. Tutu, who was awarded the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize for his role in the anti-apartheid struggle in South Africa, said Sunday that Zimbabwe made a mockery of African democracy and alienated Western donors. *  MOGADISHU, Somalia -- Militiamen fired in the direction of the speaker of Somalia's parliament as he and his delegation toured the capital's port, highlighting the challenge his government-in-exile faces as it considers returning home. No one was reported hurt. The militiamen, apparently firing from across the bay, shot near where the speaker, Shariif Hassan Sheikh Aden, was standing. Aden and about 60 lawmakers and cabinet ministers are assessing conditions in this war-ravaged country -- where they have no army or civil service -- in preparation for the government's scheduled return from Kenya this month. *  BANDA ACEH, Indonesia -- The United Nations said governments have given only a fraction of the money they pledged for tsunami aid and warned that more cash was needed to fund long-term reconstruction efforts. In Sri Lanka, corruption allegations continued to hamper relief operations. Hundreds of thousands of survivors are still in need. The United Nations urged governments to deliver promised aid. Nations have pledged $977 million, but only $360 million has reached the world body, said Margareta Wahlstrom, special envoy for Secretary General Kofi Annan. *  MANILA -- Hundreds of marines were sent to reinforce troops in the southern Philippines following fighting with followers of a jailed Muslim leader that killed at least 17 soldiers and as many as 30 rebels, officials said. The clashes erupted Monday when 500 fighters loyal to jailed leader Nur Misuari attacked government troops following an assault on their stronghold near Panamao, where guerrillas of the al Qaeda-linked Abu Sayyaf movement had allegedly sought refuge, the military said. *  GENEVA -- A U.N. human rights investigator criticized Iran over "arbitrary arrests, torture and ill treatment" of women and called on the Tehran authorities to abolish the death penalty. Yakin Erturk, a Turkish law professor, also urged the theocratic government to adopt an action plan to promote and protect human rights that would emphasize the elimination of violence against women. *  SAN SALVADOR -- El Salvador will replace its 380 troops in Iraq this week in a rotation of forces, the government said. El Salvador is one of a shrinking number of countries with troops deployed in the U.S.-led force in Iraq. El Salvador is the only Latin American country with troops in Iraq after Nicaragua, Honduras and the Dominican Republic pulled their forces out. --  From News Services

To the Editor: Nicholas D. Kristof's column about Gabon's new national parks (''Visiting Africa's Eden,'' May 16) mentions the country's oil-fueled corruption only in passing. The decades of misuse of oil revenues are at the core of Gabon's poverty paradox. Anti-corruption campaigners trying to uncover missing millions have been harassed and jailed. A United States Senate investigation published in February showed that former President Omar Bongo used loopholes in United States laws to transfer millions to bank accounts of American lobbyists. The Senate can directly help Gabonese activists and others around the world by passing the bipartisan Energy Security Through Transparency Act (S. 1700). The proposed law would require any oil company registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission to disclose its payments to foreign governments around the world. At a minimum, Gabon will need good governance and transparency if it has any hope of becoming Africa's Costa Rica. Ian Gary Senior Policy Manager Extractive Industries Oxfam America Washington, May 16, 2010

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (95%); NIGERIA (95%); AFRICA (94%); NIGER (92%); SAUDI ARABIA (79%); WESTERN AFRICA (79%); SUB SAHARAN AFRICA (79%); VENEZUELA, BOLIVARIAN REPUBLIC OF (79%); IRAN, ISLAMIC REPUBLIC OF (79%); IRAQ (79%)
TEXT: Mayhem in Nigeria, the fifth-largest oil supplier to the United States and Africa's most populous country, is escalating. Since mid-December, crime and violence have regularly shut down about 10 percent of the country's oil output. In the last week, production has been cut by nearly 20 percent -- a shortfall of 455,000 barrels daily -- amid kidnappings of foreign workers, arson against offshore oil installations, bombings of pipelines and lethal clashes between Muslims and Christians. The economic impact of the loss of Nigerian oil is magnified by other circumstances: the worsening of Iraq's oil industry, the nuclear impasse with Iran, heightening tension with Venezuela and last week's attempted suicide bombings at the main oil processing center in Saudi Arabia. The price of a barrel of crude oil spiked on Friday to nearly $63 and is unlikely to ease soon. But the world needs a stable Nigeria for reasons that go beyond oil. Nigeria is crucial to all of West Africa, having often provided the military troops and negotiating forums to quell civil war and related violence in neighboring countries. Nigeria is also important to counterterrorism efforts, both as it tries to monitor and defuse an encroaching fundamentalism among its own Muslims and in cooperating with international efforts to secure the strategically vital Gulf of Guinea. Nigeria is also now on the front lines of combating bird flu. Unfortunately, there are no easy answers to Nigeria's troubles. A big part of the problem is that the people of the country's oil-rich Niger Delta remain deeply impoverished, largely because of endemic corruption in distributing oil wealth and the historical indifference of oil companies to those economic inequities and to environmental devastation in the Delta. At the same time, the militants who claim to represent the Delta people have evolved into criminal gangs, adept at stealing huge amounts of oil to sell on black markets, the proceeds of which are used to buy ever more sophisticated weapons. Some of the current violence is a backlash against the Nigerian government's recent anti-corruption successes. But over all, Nigeria is not strong enough to solve its own problems. The Bush administration, with its good relations with Nigeria and with oil companies, is unusually well positioned to broker international arrangements that would enhance transparency in the flow of oil dollars and development in the Niger Delta. Sub-Saharan Africa is on track to double its oil production in the next 10 years, when it will likely supply up to one-fourth of America's imported oil, much of it from Nigeria. Now is the time for the American government to pay more attention to this region.

The American ambassador to Kenya, William M. Bellamy, said the United States would withhold about $2.5 million intended to help Kenya fight corruption because Kenyan officials were not seriously addressing the problem. The announcement came a day after Kenya's anti-corruption czar, John Githongo, resigned out of frustration with continuing graft in the government. President Mwai Kibaki won election in December 2002 on an anti-corruption platform, but graft has continued to thrive under his government.   Marc Lacey (NYT)

TEXT: A survey of government accountability and openness in 25 countries around the globe has found that each one is challenged by corruption and lacks sufficient protections against electoral abuses, including developed democracies such as the United States, Germany and Japan. The year-long effort involved 150 journalists, social scientists and researchers on six continents under the supervision of a nonpartisan Washington-based group, the Center for Public Integrity. The resulting report, released yesterday, produced a ranking of nations in which none was labeled "very strong" on integrity of key institutions and accountability to the public. The United States was joined by Portugal, Australia, Italy, Germany and South Africa in receiving a "strong" rating, while seven countries in Asia, Latin America and Africa received "moderate" ratings. Russia joined Panama, Indonesia, Kenya and six other countries in being rated "weak." Guatemala and Zimbabwe fell below that level. "This study shows that no country, regardless of wealth, size or population, is immune from corruption" and its ensuing problems, said Charles Lewis, the center's executive director. He said the study was meant to illuminate the "true extent and specific nature of abuses of power" around the globe and to help the public press for reforms. In comparing nations on a rudimentary scale of anti-corruption mechanisms, the center joins a growing number of groups shining a spotlight on governance problems that have historically been given short shrift by U.S. and allied governments, as well as by the World Bank, the European Union and other major aid donors. Only in the  past decade has corruption been regarded by key international funders as a serious hindrance to development, and only in the  past two years -- under a controversial Bush administration foreign aid program known as the Millennium Challenge  Account -- has the United States emphasized good governance as a key condition for economic assistance. But donors' attitudes toward corruption are slowly being changed by the work of groups such as Transparency International, which annually surveys corruption in 34 countries with financial support from Britain, Germany, the United States and private foundations. "Legal regimes governing political finance are generally inadequate" everywhere, Transparency International said in its 2004 report, explaining that no regulations exist in one-third of the countries and that enforcement is weak in many others. It also cautioned that corruption has been pervasive in the former communist countries set this weekend to join the  EU, which lacks a comprehensive anti-corruption strategy. Similar warnings have been made by the American Bar Association, which recently prepared a judicial reform index and surveyed institutional shortcomings in 15 struggling Central European and Eurasian nations. According to the Center for Public Integrity's survey -- which Lewis called "a work in progress" that he wants to expand to 25 additional nations next year -- particular shortcomings exist in mechanisms to ensure that elections are free and fair, a key test of democracy. Turkey, for example, now trying to clear a series of hurdles so it can eventually join the  EU, lacks laws providing for public audits of political party finances and public access to reports about campaign financing and candidate assets. Turkey's head of state, and those in 13 other countries in the survey, cannot be prosecuted for corruption. Turkey also scored its "weak" ranking because journalists there have been harmed or imprisoned for investigating corruption, a circumstance it shared with 16 other nations, and because the ruling party controls two-thirds or more of the parliamentary seats -- a feature shared by five other countries. More-developed countries were not above reproach, however. Australia, Germany, India, Italy and Japan  were criticized because the top official in each of those countries -- as well as in Namibia and Zimbabwe -- is not legally obligated to disclose publicly all personal assets. Although the United States was rated strong or very strong in nearly every index measure, it was faulted in particular for lacking a national ombudsman -- along with four others of the 25 nations surveyed -- and for ineffective protections of government whistle-blowers. Lewis also sharply criticized the climate in Washington in which former officials and relatives of top officials in the Bush and Clinton administrations have profited from their access to decision makers. "It's not Indonesia, Nigeria or Russia that boasts such an unabashed, mercenary culture in which influence peddlers so shamelessly cash in . . . but the United States," Lewis said. Private gain from public life, he noted, is both common and legal here.

COUNTRY: UNITED STATES (98%); AFGHANISTAN (96%); EGYPT (93%); KENYA (92%); BOLIVIA (79%); MIDDLE EAST (79%); COLOMBIA (79%); AFRICA (79%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%)
TEXT: KABUL, Afghanistan  --  A bomb killed four U.S. troops traveling in an armored vehicle Monday in volatile Uruzgan province, the deadliest loss for the U.S. military in Afghanistan in four months. Five Afghan members of a U.S.-backed militia also were killed in a firefight in the southern province of Helmand, officials said. The U.S. troops were patrolling with Afghan soldiers along a valley road in the Dihrawud district when they were attacked, said Lt. Mike Cody, a U.S. military spokesman. Shortly after the blast, gunmen opened fire with small arms and rocket-propelled grenades. Troops fought back and called in attack helicopters and fighter planes, a military statement said. The bombing raised the death toll of U.S. personnel in the Afghan war to 214 since the 2001 U.S.-led invasion. *  CAIRO  --  A decree by President Hosni Mubarak that effectively postpones local elections by extending the terms of thousands of political allies for two years drew an angry response from the Muslim Brotherhood, Egypt's largest opposition  group. The terms of local council members were scheduled to expire Tuesday, and by law, elections were to be scheduled within 60 days. But Mubarak issued a decree extending the terms to six years. The councils are considered crucial institutions of centralized state control in Egypt. The measure still needs approval by the lower house, where Mubarak's National Democratic Party holds a solid majority. *  NAIROBI  --  Two government ministers resigned after they were linked to corruption scandals that have shaken Kenyan President Mwai Kibaki's government and angered foreign donors to the East African nation. George Saitoti, the education minister, served as finance minister during the billion-dollar scandal in which public funds were stolen in a bogus gold and diamond export scheme. Kiraitu Murungi, the energy minister, has featured prominently in another scandal and has been accused of pressuring a former anti-corruption chief. *  LA PAZ, Bolivia  --  President Evo Morales called on the Bush administration to deport former president Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada to face charges related to bloody protests that preceded his resignation in 2003. Morales made the appeal during a Mass for more than 30 protesters and police officers killed in unrest in La Paz during February 2003. Violence in October of that year claimed 67 lives and led Sanchez de Lozada to quit and flee to the United States. *  BOGOTA, Colombia  --  U.N. investigators documented an increase in allegations of extrajudicial executions attributed to soldiers and police, who often presented such incidents as deaths of Marxist guerrillas in combat, according to the 2005 report from the High Commissioner for Human Rights. --  From News Services

Parliament began debating whether to pursue impeachment proceedings against President Levy Mwanawasa, who has angered some with his anti-corruption drive and his handling of the economy. The opposition United Party for National Development filed a motion on Friday that accuses Mr. Mwanawasa of misconduct, corruption and flouting the Constitution. It could be several days before legislators vote on whether the chief justice should form a tribunal to investigate the allegations or throw out the motion.

COUNTRY: ZAMBIA (94%); NIGERIA (93%); UNITED KINGDOM (92%); LIBERIA (92%); SWITZERLAND (90%); SUDAN (79%); LIECHTENSTEIN (79%); SOUTHERN AFRICA (79%); KENYA (79%); FRANCE (73%)
TEXT: While many of his people lived in squalor, dictator Mobutu Sese Seko shopped, visited doctors and kept palatial villas in France and Switzerland. When Mobutu died in 1997, having been ousted after more than 30 years in power, many assumed that there was a fortune to be recovered. But little was found in Western bank accounts linked to him. "I just don't think there was very much left," said Richard Dowden, head of Britain's Royal African Society. "He had to pay off a lot of people. I think his family robbed him rotten. So there wasn't a great heap of wealth to be found." After Mwai Kibaki won the presidency in 2002 on an anti-corruption platform, his aides estimated that as much as $4 billion in government assets had been stolen and spirited abroad under his predecessor, Daniel arap Moi. Kroll Associates, an international security and investigations firm, was brought in to trace the funds. Kroll and the government report that some money was found, but won't say more, and efforts to bring it home have stalled. Kibaki may be finding it politically difficult to proceed against Moi, who remains a powerful figure with an involvement in peace efforts in neighboring Sudan. Also, Kibaki has problems with allegations of corruption within his own government. Not only is ousted President Charles Taylor accused of looting the Liberian treasury during his 1997-2003 tenure, but businesses linked to him are believed to still be funneling cash stolen from state coffers to the former warlord in exile in Nigeria. Little has been done about it under a transitional government, itself accused of corruption, that is to hand power over to an elected government this year. According to U.N. investigators, the "modus operandi followed by the top functionaries of the [transitional] government in siphoning off government revenues for various licit or illicit purposes appears to be the same as that used by the Taylor regime." The government says military dictator Sani Abacha stole more than $2.2 billion from the oil-rich nation from 1993, when he seized power, until his death in 1998. Using diplomacy and the courts, Nigeria has been pushing with some success for the return of Abacha's looted funds from Austria, Britain, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Switzerland and elsewhere. Former president Frederick Chiluba is charged in Zambian courts with 169 counts of corruption, abuse of power and theft totaling $43 million, and 65 counts of state theft totaling about $3.5 million. Last year, a London court, at the request of Zambian prosecutors, froze $24 million in assets held by Chiluba in Britain. Chiluba, Zambia's first democratically elected president, led the southern African country from 1991 until 2002. --  Associated Press

COUNTRY: ZAMBIA (98%); ZIMBABWE (94%); AFRICA (94%); EGYPT (93%); FRANCE (92%); UNITED STATES (79%)
TEXT: Levy Mwanawasa, 59, the president of Zambia, whose criticism of the political and economic crisis of neighboring Zimbabwe helped break the traditional silence of African leaders toward one of their own, died Aug. 19 at a hospital in Paris after a stroke. Mr. Mwanawasa suffered a stroke June 29 at an African Union summit in Egypt. He was flown to Paris for treatment July 1. He had a reputation for integrity and fought corruption in his country but never managed to lift the Zambian people out of crushing poverty. Mr. Mwanawasa was Zambia's third president since independence from Britain in 1964 and was not bound by the liberation movement ties of older African leaders. He was the first among them to criticize autocratic Zimbabwe President Robert Mugabe, who had long been revered as an African independence hero. Mr. Mwanawasa's death leaves a power vacuum in Zambia, one of the world's biggest copper producers. Under the constitution, elections should be held within 90 days. Levy Patrick Mwanawasa was born Sept. 3, 1948, in Mufulira in what was then Northern Rhodesia. He graduated from the University of Zambia and practiced law before entering government service. After a stint as solicitor general in 1986, he soon became a key figure in the push for multiparty democracy. When Frederick Chiluba defeated Zambia's first president, Kenneth Kaunda, in Zambia's first multiparty elections in 1991, Mr. Mwanawasa was appointed vice president. He then quit, complaining of corruption. Even so, Chiluba chose Mr. Mwanawasa to be his successor. Mr. Mwanawasa won the presidency in 2001 in an election marred by allegations of fraud and was reelected in 2006 with 43 percent of the vote in an election that was generally regarded as fair. As he sought to establish his legitimacy in his first term, Mr. Mwanawasa seized on anti-corruption and economic changes and targeted Chiluba, who was found guilty in a London court of stealing $46 million from state coffers during his 10-year rule. Mr. Mwanawasa won praise from the business community and middle class Zambians as well as many Western donors and investors for his free market policies. He tamed inflation and, after years of economic stagnation, presided over a period of growth helped by a boom in global copper prices. Mr. Mwanawasa's economic austerity and market-opening policies drew support from the United States, the World Bank and lending institutions, which agreed in 2005 to cancel nearly all of Zambia's $7.2 billion foreign debt. Critics accused Mr. Mwanawasa of turning a blind eye to the plight of the poor in a country where less than 20 percent of the population has formal employment and the majority lives below the poverty line. Opponents also said Mr. Mwanawasa pandered to the whims of Western donors. Mr. Mwanawasa countered that it was thanks to the forgiveness of foreign debt that he was able to increase spending on education and health. Populist rival Michael Sata and other critics also said he was too subservient to China, which poured hundreds of millions of dollars into Zambia's copper sector. Mr. Mwanawasa accused the West of failing to follow through on promises of increased aid and trade. Africa "is in the hands of Europe" but needs China's economic aid, Mr. Mwanawasa told an audience of U.S. students last year. "You people in the West redeem yourself before you begin attacking China," he said.

Levy Mwanawasa, Zambia's new president, has big plans for his time in office, and no one is finding that harder to swallow than the man who put him there, his predecessor, Frederick Chiluba. After 10 years in office and an aborted effort to stay on beyond the constitutional limit, Mr. Chiluba chose Mr. Mwanawasa to be their party's candidate last year, apparently confident that his chosen successor would safeguard the darkest secrets of a government that, by many accounts, stole with little fear and even less shame. Following recent disclosures about questionable state payments and allegations of other corruption, no one -- and certainly not Mr. Chiluba -- thinks secrets are safe anymore. With the new president pushing Parliament to lift Mr. Chiluba's immunity from prosecution, the coming months could land Mr. Chiluba in court and perhaps even in prison. With his crackdown, Mr. Mwanawasa has managed to dodge some of the questions about his own election, winning applause from people who had questioned the legitimacy of his victory and from skeptics who had predicted that he would be Mr. Chiluba's puppet. Zambia is among the world's most corrupt countries, according to Transparency International, an advocacy group that tracks corruption worldwide. As the link between corruption and poverty grows clearer, citizens appear to be insisting on greater accountability. "Our people have woken up to the fact that it is their responsibility to improve their lot," said Mutembo Nchito, a 33-year-old lawyer who has emerged as a champion of cleaner government. "I think it's really re-ignited a sense of patriotism. We're ashamed of the way the country was plundered, but we're really proud of the way we're handling it." Even the initial snipes about the mental fitness of Mr. Mwanawasa, who was being called "The Cabbage" on account of his deliberate speaking style, have subsided as the nation has warmed to his hard-charging agenda. But he is also rousing anger among powerful people, who contend that he is setting up his own downfall. Cryptic talk of a plot to unseat him or even assassinate him is popping up, most of it from the state news outlets that he controls. "I am not targeting anybody," he said in an interview at State House, the presidential residence and office. "I am not witch hunting. This is not a war by one individual. This is not a war by Levy Mwanawasa. The people of Zambia have said no." Yet, Mr. Mwanawasa's campaign against corruption is very much playing out as a duel between the two men, and so far Mr. Mwanawasa is scoring all the points. In the most remarkable turn so far, Mr. Chiluba's spymaster, Xavier Chungu, was arrested in June and charged with using an intelligence agency bank account in London to funnel secret payments that reached people ranging from Mr. Chiluba's children to Zambia's ambassador to the United States, Atan Shansonga, who was summoned back to Lusaka, the capital, and arrested. The bank account was brought to light in June by Mr. Nchito, who is defending two local journalists and two legislators against charges that they defamed the president last year when they called Mr. Chiluba a thief. Details of the many transactions, which were among records released by Mr. Mwanawasa's government after Mr. Nchito's petition, are still emerging. Some payments could turn out to be aboveboard, but the fallout already suggests otherwise. The country's chief justice, suspected of receiving $168,000, has stepped down. So has the foreign minister, Katele Kalumba, who was Mr. Chiluba's finance minister and was suspected of receiving several thousand dollars from the account. Mr. Kalumba disappeared and was rumored to have killed himself. With crowds of demonstrators urging members on, Parliament took up President Mwanawasa's call to lift Mr. Chiluba's immunity. Mr. Chiluba's lawyers quickly brought an appeal before the High Court, and Parliament's vote was stayed. A hearing on the matter is scheduled for today. Each day brings another twist. Perhaps hoping to balance tough talk with magnanimity, Mr. Mwanawasa raised the possibility of pardoning Mr. Chiluba -- if he returns the money he is said to have stolen. Mr. Chiluba, a trade union leader who helped found the Movement for Multiparty Democracy, came to power in 1991, ending 27 years of authoritarian, largely one-party rule under the independence hero, Kenneth Kaunda. Mr. Mwanawasa, another founder of the party, was vice president until 1994, when he quit, saying he was disgusted with his party's unabashed corruption. Plucked back into politics from the private law practice to which he had retreated, he seemed a shrewd, if unlikely, choice to be the party's candidate in the elections last December. Party leaders reasoned that his long absence from government would would spare him the taint of corruption, while his long association with the party would ensure loyalty. "It was a mistake, it seems," Mr. Chiluba said in an interview at his home here in Lusaka when asked about his decision to nominate Mr. Mwanawasa. "I am disappointed. I had a lot of faith in my brother Levy Mwanawasa, and he has let me down greatly, I must say." A lay minister, Mr. Chiluba said that he was not guilty of any criminal wrongdoing as president and that the questions in recent months could have been resolved quietly. Mr. Chiluba said: "I think decency would have demanded that the president comes to me and says, 'What have you done, my brother? Can you explain?' If I fail, indeed, he is the head of state and he can say then, 'I don't brook this nonsense.' "But none of this has ever happened," he continued. "I'm wading from one accusation to another, from one indictment to another, and it's becoming a little hard to bear." Mr. Mwanawasa is unmoved by his predecessor's complaints. "Now he feels betrayed by the fact that we have revealed what appears to be plunder?" Mr. Mwanawasa said. "I don't feel I betrayed him. I would have betrayed the people of Zambia if I did not disclose this." Whatever the scheme, the plundering of places like Zambia ultimately deprives poor people of the most basic human needs, like nutritious food, while enriching a tiny elite. Years of watching such coteries act with impunity have imbued even the poor with a warped sense of entitlement, said Bradford Malumbe, the chief of operations for the country's anti-corruption commission. Stealing something as ordinary as a fuse from a traffic light is condoned by the community, he said. "We are working very hard with civil society to get the message across that what you see out there belongs to you not as an individual but as a society," he said. Nothing will do that more effectively, said Mr. Nchito, the lawyer, than a successful prosecution of Mr. Chiluba. "That will burn the rule of law onto the consciences of our people, and no one will be able to reverse it."

Zambian officials began tallying ballots early Friday after a huge turnout in close elections fought on a debate over President Levy Mwanawasa's economic policies. International donors had praised his actions, but the opposition denounced them for failing to lift millions out of poverty. Mwanawasa urged voters to back his record of strict financial discipline and zero tolerance of corruption, policies that have earned Zambia relief from debts and commendation from the International Monetary Fund and other donors. His populist challenger, Michael Sata, accused the incumbent of "selling out" Zambia to donors and foreign firms, particularly from China, who are interested in the country's huge copper reserves. Different opinion polls have tipped both Mwanawasa and Sata to win, meaning Thursday's vote could be the closest in the southern Africa country since it won independence from Britain in 1964. Analysts said the count would be watched closely by voters, who are divided over the competing visions of Zambia's future advanced by the two main candidates. Frequent and at times obvious voter fraud has marred previous elections. Election officials said the vote this year was nearly flawless, except for a few instances, criticized by Sata's Patriotic Front, in which voters were erroneously omitted from registers. A third candidate in the presidential race, Hakainde Hichilema of the United Democratic Alliance, is expected to come in third, despite an endorsement by liberation hero and former president Kenneth Kaunda as the "best man to lead Zambia." After the 2001 election, the opposition petitioned the Supreme Court to nullify Mwanawasa's victory, saying the vote was rigged, but the court dismissed the accusations. Zambia's electoral commission introduced measures to try to ensure free and fair elections this time, including satellite technology to transmit poll results and the use of transparent ballot boxes. It is unclear when the winner will be declared. Under a new electoral law, the news media are forbidden to project a winner based on partial results, although poll watchers expect the final count by Saturday or Sunday. Mwanawasa, a burly lawyer who made an early mark with an anti-corruption drive targeting former president Frederick Chiluba, has sought to highlight an economic record that, in addition to winning debt relief, has cut poverty and pushed economic growth above 5 percent. He has repeatedly called the election a referendum on Zambia's economic future. Sata has won support by promising workers a bigger stake in state enterprises, major tax cuts and a 51 percent cap on foreign mine ownership. His rallies have been packed with supporters who say the Mwanawasa team has failed to bring the benefits of Zambia's economic revitalization to the estimated two-thirds of Zambia's 11.5 million people who still live on less than $1 a day.

TEXT: HARARE, Zimbabwe -- The editor of Zimbabwe's only independent daily newspaper and three colleagues were in police custody yesterday over a report alleging police vehicles were used during a wave of looting of white-owned farms. Geoff Nyarota, editor-in-chief of the Daily News, assistant editor Bill Saidi, news editor John Gabanga and reporter Sam Sam Munyavi were all being held at Harare's central police station, the newspaper's spokesman said. "It looks like they are all spending the night in custody," the spokesman said. Daily News executive Thomas Deve said he suspected the men were being held over a report in his newspaper that alleged the police had been involved in looting white-owned farms. Chief police spokesman, assistant commissioner Wayne Bvudzijena, confirmed Nyarota's arrest, but said he was not aware his three colleagues had also been detained. "He has been charged under section 50 (2a) of LOMA which forbids the publication of false news likely to cause alarm and despondency," Bvudzijena said. Reuters NAIROBI -- The International Monetary Fund announced that lending to Kenya would remain suspended after the country's parliament rejected a key piece of anti-corruption legislation. Business leaders said the decision would rip a $ 300 million hole in the government's budget and plunge the country's economy deeper into crisis. The government says it still hopes to persuade the IMF to restore lending, but diplomats said the government instead needed to persuade opposition parties to pass some kind of modified legislation. Opposition leader Mwai Kibaki, of the Democratic Party, said the government proposal was full of discrepancies and fell short of what would be necessary to fight corruption. Parliament voted 130 to 82 Tuesday for a bill paving the way for the establishment of a body to fight official corruption, a key piece of legislation demanded by the IMF as a condition for releasing suspended loans. However, the support fell short of the 145 votes needed to pass the constitutional amendment. ReutersEUROPE VIENNA -- A day after her release from an Italian prison, an American jailed for three weeks after the Group of Eight summit in Genoa said she would fight for the release of other "political prisoners." Susanna Thomas, 21, a Quaker from New Jersey, said her time in prison had brought her closer to others arrested in connection with the protests at the summit last month. "We shared a toothbrush. We shared soap, chocolate, cigarettes and all the little things that make life pleasurable. And most of all," she said, "we shared support." Thomas was among 20 people ordered released by a Genoa court Tuesday. The group was made up of 15 Austrians, three Americans, a Slovak and a Swede. Several others are still detained, including at least 10 Germans accused of being members of the anarchist Black Bloc group. Arriving at Vienna's airport from Milan, Thomas promised to do all she could to support the other detainees. She still faces charges that could lead to a 15-year prison sentence. "The story is still going on," she said. "All the Genoese political prisoners need help and support and solidarity." Associated Press LOURDES, France -- A Spanish man packed his car with explosives and set it on fire after ramming through the entrance to the Lourdes Sanctuary, where 40,000 people were attending Mass, officials said. No one was injured in the attack, which occurred during a ceremony to mark the Assumption Day holiday. After the man, described as a local resident in his seventies, bashed through one of the portals of the Lourdes complex in southwest France, he stopped his car and set it on fire. LCI television quoted a witness as saying that the man doused his car seats with gasoline and lit the fire while still inside the vehicle. Security guards immediately pulled the man from the car and extinguished the flames, state prosecutor Yves Saint-Macary said. The car was loaded with Molotov cocktails, gas canisters, bags of nails, a loaded rifle and hundreds of cartridges, officials said. The man told authorities he was trying to commit suicide and had no religious or political motive, Saint-Macary said. When President Nelson Mandela's government appointed Ramesh Vassen this year to be South Africa's consul general to India, critics said the attorney, who was disbarred for stealing money from client trust funds, wasn't fit for a diplomatic post. Mandela and his top officials defended their choice but eventually conceded that Vassen's appointment had to be withdrawn. When Mandela's ruling African National Congress listed party official Patrick Matosa as a candidate for the June 2 parliamentary election, critics said that a man convicted of threatening a police officer with a gun wasn't fit to run for office. The ANC initially stood by Matosa, but his candidacy ultimately also was withdrawn. In a nation in the throes of what Deputy President Thabo Mbeki, the ANC's leader, recently called a "threatening state of moral degradation," the Vassen and Matosa cases illustrate what some see as governmental ambivalence toward ethical laxness and corruption, sometimes reflecting a conflict between party loyalty and party discipline within the ANC. With South Africa's second democratic election only six weeks away, corruption, along with violent crime, has become one of the hottest campaign issues. Opposition parties accuse Mandela's ANC of being soft on corruption, especially when it comes to figures with anti-apartheid "struggle credentials," such as Vassen, who once worked in the civil rights law firm of the current justice minister. Because South Africa's political field remains racially divided, these criticisms -- which come mostly from white opposition groups -- strike some blacks here as racist attacks on black rule itself. The ANC counters that corruption is a product of the moral decay inherited from the years of apartheid, the repressive racial separation policy that underpinned white-minority rule. But the problem is so alarming that Mandela and Mbeki, who is virtually certain to become president after the June ballot, have in recent weeks repeatedly decried corruption. Barreling into the sacrosanct status of party faithful who once were beyond public reproach, Mandela recently lambasted fellow "freedom fighters" for becoming corrupt bureaucrats. "We came into government with the intention of cleaning the civil service of corruption," Mandela said. "But our freedom fighters, some of them very top activists, when they got the opportunity, also stole taxpayers' money." George Bizos, widely regarded to be South Africa's most dogged and famed human rights lawyer and a loyalist of the anti-apartheid struggle, says that the techniques of that struggle have lent themselves to crime and corruption following the demise of white rule and the entry of former anti-apartheid guerrillas into government. "The deviousness needed to fight the apartheid system is deep rooted and now is being used" by foes of apartheid who have turned dirty, he said. "Our society's values require upliftment." Examples of corruption abound: Provincial government officials accused of stealing public funds, particularly in Mpumalanga Province east of Johannesburg. An investigation of the nation's top immigration official, Albert Mokoena, director general of Home Affairs, for allegedly giving false IDs to foreign players on a basketball team he allegedly managed from his government office. Some 10,000 police -- out of a force of about 120,000 -- arrested by the end of 1997 in connection with crimes such as theft and armed robbery, according to a Safety and Security Ministry report to Parliament. Sophisticated white-collar syndicates, presumably with the aid of civil servants, have defrauded pension funds and housing subsidy programs of millions of dollars intended to help the elderly and poor. Such housing and pension scams are the bulk of the 90,000 cases, valued at about $ 1.5 billion, that are being probed by the Heath Special Investigations Unit, an anti-corruption body established in 1996. The unit is charged with investigating corruption and recovering government funds. Revelations of corruption have surged since 1994, when South Africa's first all-races election brought an end to apartheid. But officials here, including anti-corruption investigators, say corruption was systemically rife, even at the highest levels of government, during the decades of white-minority rule. It was kept undercover and was generally sanctioned, they say, by the nation's white rulers. Indeed, the current government's leading anti-corruption investigator, Justice Willem Heath, said recently that he is probing cases from the apartheid era that include two or three former cabinet ministers. In the days of apartheid, said Heath, "the corruption was very high up." He could not say the same for the current government. In addition to Heath's presidentially mandated special investigative unit, corruption is investigated by the National Public Protector, the auditor general, the public service commission, police anti-corruption units and an independent police watchdog group. The ANC says that the existence of these bodies, which the ANC-led government created, shows the seriousness of its commitment to fight corruption. "Today we are able to talk about corruption because of the transparency the ANC has brought . . . to not only discover corruption but to prevent it from happening," chief ANC spokesman Thabo Masebe said of the government's anti-corruption drive. But Heath, who has been fighting the government over unit funding, questions the commitment to fighting corruption. "They are completely unwise not to invest more in the unit," Heath said. "So yes, maybe one could draw the inference that they are not as serious as they claim to be." Opposition leaders such as Tony Leon of the small, predominantly white Democratic Party, question why the ANC closed ranks around its controversial health minister, Nkosazana Zuma, instead of holding her accountable for the disappearance of roughly $ 2 million from a special anti-AIDS project she had sanctioned. Last week, Heath dropped his investigation of Zuma because she was not the Health Ministry's accounting officer and therefore could not be held responsible for the missing money, Heath unit officials said. This political war over ethics and accountability is likely to heat up as the vote approaches, for high on the ANC election list -- and not to be removed, Mbeki says -- is one of the most popular yet controversial figures of all: Winnie Madikizela-Mandela. The president's former wife, who kept the Mandela name in the public eye while Nelson Mandela served 27 years of political imprisonment, has solid credentials as a key foe of apartheid. She also has a criminal record: her 1991 conviction for the kidnapping of a young anti-apartheid activist who was found murdered. Mbeki says nation is in "threatening state of moral degradation." Mandela has lambasted "freedom fighters" for becoming corrupt.

The head of Kenya's new anti-corruption authority has been suspended from office after a disagreement with the Finance Minister in a case that underscores just how difficult it is to root out graft here. President Daniel arap Moi suspended the official, John Harun Mwau, on Wednesday, just four days after Mr. Mwau had filed charges against four high-ranking Treasury Department officials, accusing them of a scheme to evade $3.9 million in import duties on wheat and sugar. The President's actions came after the Finance Minister, Simeon Nyachae, in a spirited defense of his accused subordinates, attacked Mr. Mwau in public, accusing him of starting a witch hunt. He defended the officials, who are accused of corrupt business dealings, maintaining that not only did they act within the law, but with the full approval of the Cabinet. Played out on the front pages of newspapers here, the disagreement has undermined the credibility of Mr. Moi's efforts to stamp out corruption, once again putting Kenya's shaky relations with international lenders in jeopardy. "This is not helpful," said one diplomat, insisting on anonymity. "This is an unfortunate development, distracting from the central issues this country faces. This is all a distraction, a sideshow." When the International Monetary Fund suspended aid to Kenya last year, one of its principal complaints was that the Government had done little or nothing to rein in rampant official corruption. In recent years, corrupt schemes have seeped into almost every level of government here, from bribes that traffic officers solicit from motorists to elaborate land grabs and import-duty scams involving cabinet members, diplomats say. In response to pressure from the I.M.F., Mr. Moi set up the Kenya Anti-Corruption Authority last December and put Mr. Mwau, a former police officer and an opposition gadfly, in charge. But Mr. Mwau's decision to prosecute the four treasury officials as his first high-profile case has raised questions about his sincerity and the viability of his authority, diplomats and financial officials said. Before the charges were leveled, the four accused officials were seen as part of a progressive, reform-minded wing of the governing party, a group led by Mr. Nyachae that stands firmly behind efforts to stamp out corruption. While diplomats and officials at international lending institutions said they could not say whether the charges were true, they did say they came as a surprise. "We have a feeling that these people who were to be arrested were doing their jobs and we have no reason to believe they were corrupt," one banking official said, speaking on the condition of anonymity. Whether or not the charges are true, several diplomats said the public contretemps was not likely to persuade the I.M.F. and World Bank to resume aid to shore up Kenya's shattered economy, which is reeling from a steep drop in tourism. On the streets of the capital, meanwhile, speculation has grown that Mr. Mwau purposely took aim at pro-reform officials first, instead of other officials suspected of corruption in order to take the wind out of the pro-reform movement's sails. A cartoon in Wednesday's Daily Nation newspaper showed Mr. Mwau and Mr. Nyachae as puppets, their strings being pulled by hands recognizable as the President's. A statement from the President's office said Mr. Moi would appoint a tribunal to "inquire into the proper performance" of the corruption authority. The statement said Mr. Mwau would be suspended until the tribunal had finished its inquiry. For his part, Mr. Mwau has fiercely defended the charges against the four officials and has said he will resign if they are not proved true in court. It is highly unlikely the case will ever be heard, however, since the Attorney General has dropped the charges. The accused officials are Joseph Kinyua, Njeru Kirira, John Msafari and Samuel Chebii. At the same time, Mr. Nyachae has accused Mr. Mwau of pressing the charges only to divert attention from the fact that he himself is under investigation by the Kenya Revenue Authority for evading duty on the import of automobile tires. Mr. Mwau denies any wrongdoing.

In West Africa, where pop stars sometimes take on the role of the traditional storyteller-historians called griots, several band leaders have achieved mythic status. But none has been as commanding as Fela Kuti, who died in 1997, reportedly of AIDS. The singer and saxophonist was a prolific musician who recorded more than 50 albums in the style he dubbed Afro-beat, but he also was an outspoken critic of Nigeria's succession of corrupt military and civilian governments. Among his best-known songs are such broadsides as "Zombie," "Shuffering and Shmiling" and "Coffin for Head of State." These and 10 other songs are included on "The Best Best of Fela Kuti" (MCA), a new two-CD set that presages the reissue of much of the musician's back catalogue. Fela's compositions are sprawling vamps that incorporate American jazz and funk as well as such traditional African devices as call-and-response vocals. Most of the tracks on "Best Best" are edited or partial versions, yet still run an average of more than 12 minutes each. Like such West African peers as King Sunny Ade--or Washington's own go-go bands--Fela dealt in expansive grooves rather than concise songs, presiding over an improvisational big-band flow into which he could interject a sax or keyboard solo, a communal chant or an anti-corruption screed. Fela's battle with Nigeria's government was not merely a matter of words: He suffered imprisonment, beatings and exile. If he didn't live to see his populist and pan-African ideals widely adopted, his music survives to continue the crusade. And unlike such equally outraged African musicians as Zimbabwe's Thomas Mapfumo, Fela sang mostly in English, so his message can also be widely understood. Listening to Fela's full output would surely be as exhausting as deciphering his mystical politics is exasperating, but distilled to these two discs his music is both fierce and approachable.  (To hear a free Sound Bite from this album, call Post-Haste at 202-334-9000 and press 8153.)  Femi Kuti: 'Shoki Shoki'  Fela's son Femi continues the family franchise with "Shoki Shoki" (MCA), an album whose style is both more disciplined and less distinctive than his father's. The younger Kuti, who performs March 22 at the 9:30 club, has modernized Afro-beat with electronics and crossover appeal. Most of the album's 12 songs (which include three remixes) run only about six minutes long, and while Femi hasn't tailored his sound for dance clubs, he does pay more attention to the underlying polyrhythms than Fela usually did. Like his father, Femi plays sax and sings in pidgin English, which he uses to deliver such generalized inspirational messages as "Truth Don Die" and "Blackman Know Yourself." But he also addresses such nonpolitical topics as the pleasure of sex ("Beng Beng Beng," which the female chorus pronounces "bang bang bang") and everyday uncertainty ("What Will Tomorrow Bring?," which features a horn-section riff straight out of early-'70s funk). Generally less caustic than Fela, Femi doesn't name names or hurl taunts. Still, when he denounces "politicians and soldiers" and makes an explicit reference to "Zombie," it's clear that Femi is continuing Fela's campaign.  (To hear a free Sound Bite from this album, call Post-Haste at 202-334-9000 and press 8154.)

When Nigeria's Senate elected its third president in 13 months last week, it sought to end a run of scandals that have entangled the legislature of the still-young civilian government. Since Nigeria's military handed power to elected officials in May 1999, the Senate has twice impeached its president, who is the country's third-ranking official, and has forced out other leaders of the legislature's upper house for alleged corruption. The speaker of the lower chamber resigned last year amid an uproar because he had faked a university degree. More than a year after President Olusegun Obasanjo and other civilian politicians took over Africa's most populous country, the repeated scandals underscore Nigeria's struggle to find its political bearings after living under military rule for 30 of its 40 years as an independent country. Official corruption remains a critical problem as Nigeria struggles to repair its economy. But for the first time in recent memory, some top government officials are being held publicly accountable for malfeasance in office. Nigeria's political stabilization is critical to American interests, U.S. officials say, a point reflected by President Clinton's scheduled visit here later this month to cement dramatically improved relations. This country is a major supplier of oil to the United States and a key partner in trying to end the war for diamonds and power in nearby Sierra Leone. Nigeria's legislature, the National Assembly, is structured much like the U.S. Congress, with a Senate and a House of Representatives. Within two months of taking office last year, the lower house ousted its speaker, Salisu Buhari, after he admitted embellishing his resume with a fictitious MBA degree from the University of Toronto. In November, the Senate impeached its president, Evan Enwerem, amid allegations that he had concealed a criminal conviction. Enwerem was replaced by Chuba Okadigbo, who in Nigeria's previous civilian government had been an aide to President Shehu Shagari. Okadigbo proved a stubborn Senate president, insisting on the legislature's independence from Obasanjo and holding up passage of the 2000 budget until last month. But last month, a Senate committee found that Okadigbo, his deputy and the Senate majority leader had colluded with others to award contracts worth millions of dollars to firms linked to them or their relatives. Okadigbo also overspent by 50 percent the $ 245,000 he was allotted to furnish his official residence and awarded himself a Christmas bonus of $ 220,000, the committee's report said. Even Nigerians who have been toughened to the profligacy of their officials were startled to learn that Okadigbo was keeping a fleet of 32 luxury cars. Joseph Wayas, the Senate president under Nigeria's previous civilian government, noted to the Nigerian media that he had gotten by with only four official cars. Amid a public uproar, Okadigbo's deputy and the majority leader resigned. But Okadigbo refused to join them, calling the investigation a political vendetta. He was impeached and removed on Aug. 8. In some ways, analysts say, the legislative scandals have advanced Obasanjo's anti-corruption campaign. "We all now know that under [former military dictator Gen. Sani] Abacha, bullion vans routinely went to the Central Bank to load millions of dollars in cash and deposit [it] at his residence, and nobody asked questions," said Lagos banker Yetunde Johnson. "But now questions are being asked and people are having to give account," he said. "It's no doubt a victory for democracy." Still, while the National Assembly has been heavily occupied with its scandals, Nigeria continues to wrestle with economic and political crises. The first legislation introduced by Obasanjo sought to use oil revenues to bring roads, electricity and other development to the long-neglected Niger Delta region. Youths of impoverished delta tribes have formed guerrilla groups that attack oil pumping stations or rival villages, and the danger of a civil upheaval among the oil fields is seen by many as Nigeria's greatest security risk. Although Obasanjo and legislative leaders have said the delta crisis is a top priority, they have been unable to agree on a bill. Last week, the Senate chose Pius Anyim, 39, an outspoken opponent of corruption, as its new president. "The combination of President Obasanjo and Anyim represents for now a potential for sobriety, honesty and integrity in the conduct of public affairs," wrote Anietie Usen, a columnist for the independent newspaper Thisday. Anyim is seen as an ally of Obasanjo in a quiet tussle for influence within the governing People's Democratic Party. The party's machinery--its top fundraisers and organizers--is dominated by a loose network of political bosses, businessmen and former military officers once close to Maj. Gen. Shehu Yar'Adua, a former Obasanjo deputy who died in prison in 1997. As military rule ended following the death of Abacha, this faction helped found the party, and only later was Obasanjo persuaded to run as its candidate. Some foreign diplomats have voiced concern at the legislative paralysis in a period when Nigeria wrestles with ethnic and religious conflicts, and the violence in the Niger River delta. But the legislature's turmoil "is not a sign of instability," said Oladapo Fafowora, a retired Nigerian diplomat. "We have just returned to full-fledged democracy after 15 years during which all structures of democracy were either destroyed or suspended. In democracy if there's a long break with the past, you'll have to start all over again."

When former Gen. Olusegun Obasanjo was inaugurated as president of Nigeria in late May, he took over a once-prosperous nation that had been reduced to misery by a series of larcenous military regimes. In the late 1970's, Mr. Obasanjo was himself Nigeria's military ruler, although the first to turn over power to a civilian. In 1995, Gen. Sani Abacha, the country's most ruthless leader, jailed him for three years. But General Obasanjo remained close to the military and, bankrolled by some of Nigeria's most nefarious officers, won elections this year. There was reason for skepticism about his intentions. Nevertheless, President Obasanjo -- who is to receive Secretary of State Madeleine Albright later this week -- has won over many of his critics by distancing himself from his former military allies, taking important steps to combat corruption and restoring political freedoms. He is now beginning economic reforms. With one important exception -- the troubles of the oil-producing Delta region -- President Obasanjo has awakened hopes that Nigeria's slide can be halted or reversed. Some of Mr. Obasanjo's actions are not only symbolically important, but can also reduce the chance of yet another military coup. On June 10 he fired 93 high-ranking officers, including all who recently occupied political posts. Mr. Obasanjo also canceled all contracts awarded by the military government in 1999, which saw billions of dollars in sweetheart deals. He has established three commissions to investigate corruption. Nigeria is freer than it has been in years. A bustling civil society is back in operation and unions are regaining influence. A new commission that will hold hearings and collect reports on serious human rights abuses has only limited powers, but it is led by respected activists. Mr. Obasanjo's efforts to revive the economy have been blessed by a sharp rise in the price of what is virtually the country's only product, oil. He has chosen a capable economic team, which has begun to reverse Nigeria's pariah status with international lenders. His most visible and popular achievement to date has been to end an absurd gasoline shortage that kept drivers waiting in line, sometimes overnight, for expensive gas. The shortage was caused by corrupt manipulation of oil supplies. Fighting corruption is Mr. Obasanjo's most important and difficult challenge.  State treasuries are so looted that many cannot pay $20-a-month teachers' salaries. Mr. Obasanjo has proposed an anti-corruption bill, and measures to cut middlemen out of state transactions. But Mr. Obasanjo, sadly, has shown little interest in one necessary measure to combat corruption and several other problems -- a new relationship between Nigeria's states and its central government, which controls most of the country's revenue. The issue is seen most dramatically in the Niger Delta. Oil money goes to the central government, where it disappears. The oil-producing Delta gets virtually nothing back to alleviate desperate poverty or clean up environmental destruction. This has radicalized many in the Delta. Youth gangs have kidnapped oil workers and sabotaged production, which has cost Nigeria billions of dollars. Security forces have responded with hundreds of killings. In early June, Mr. Obasanjo met with Delta community leaders. But his conduct and his proposals show that he sees the region mainly as a security problem. Without more local say over oil money and how it is spent, the Delta could explode. Mr. Obasanjo's greatest contribution to Nigeria's stability may eventually be his willingness to reduce his own powers. http://www.nytimes.com

Nigeria is Africa's most populous country, and potentially one of its most prosperous. But for decades, a deeply rooted culture of corruption has undermined Nigeria's economy, impoverished its people and tarnished its international reputation. It has also helped make Nigeria one of the world's leading centers of drug smuggling, including much of the narcotics that reach the United States. Now, under a new democratic government, there are encouraging signs of change. If President Olusegun Obasanjo continues his aggressive campaign against bribery, kickbacks and consumer scams, Washington and other Western governments should reward his efforts by rescheduling some of the debts Nigeria incurred under the corrupt military regimes of the past. Mr. Obasanjo came to office with a deserved reputation as a reformer. In the 1970's, he headed the only military government in Nigeria's history to freely hand power to an elected successor. Later, under the harsh 1990's dictatorship of Gen. Sani Abacha, he spent three years in prison for opposing government repression. But few expected a serious attack on corruption or a serious investigation into the abuses of his military predecessors. Mr. Obasanjo's earlier government was known for diverting oil revenues and demanding payments for licenses and contracts, and his election campaign this year had been financed by Nigeria's military establishment. But since taking office six months ago, President Obasanjo has removed hundreds of corrupt military officers and government officials and brought legal claims against their business cronies that could permit the recovery of billions of stolen dollars. Corruption still plays too big a role in Nigerian political life, and Mr. Obasanjo has shown a disturbing tendency to wink at illicit conduct by his closest political allies. But the change in Nigeria's ethical climate is pronounced. Nigeria's oil and mineral wealth should disqualify it from outright debt relief. But when Mr. Obasanjo visited Washington last month, President Clinton endorsed stretching out payments on some of Nigeria's $30 billion international debt as further reforms unfold. The administration should wait until Mr. Obasanjo's strong anti-corruption legislation overcomes parliamentary resistance. Washington should also demand compliance with international human rights standards, especially in the oil-producing Niger Delta, where the repressive policies of previous military governments are still in force. But once these conditions are met, America should help make Nigeria a showcase for the proposition that an honest, democratic government can bring a demonstrably better life to ordinary people. http://www.nytimes.com

Lorne Craner, the president of the International Republican Institute; Bill Frist, a former Republican leader of the Senate; Kenneth Hackett, the president of Catholic Relief Services; and Alan Patricof, a founder of a venture capital firm, are appointees to the Millennium Challenge Corporation's board.  AS Barack Obama works to reinvigorate America's standing in the world, foreign aid will be one of his most precise tools of statecraft. Ever since the Marshall Plan helped rebuild Europe after World War II, aid has been instrumental in winning hearts and minds and catalyzing global economic growth that has contributed to America's prosperity. But not all foreign aid is the same. Hard lessons learned over the past five decades have taught us that good governance, accountability, local ownership and long-term engagement are the keys to success. In January, the new administration will inherit the five-year-old Millennium Challenge Corporation, which was created by Congress to ensure that foreign assistance operates according to these principles. He would do well to adopt it as a core development tool. Aid works best in countries whose governments are capable and committed. Before directing any American aid to a country, the corporation measures its performance on 17 indicators of democratic government, anti-corruption efforts, investments in health and education (particularly for girls) and economic freedom. Only those countries that perform strongly are allowed to compete for a five-year compact that makes them eligible to receive American aid for programs intended to reduce poverty and stimulate economic growth. By building its program around independent measures of policy performance, the corporation has been able to catalyze reform in poor countries -- sometimes before any aid money is spent. Burkina Faso, one of the  poorest countries in the world, has committed to improving girls' primary education. And in Guatemala, which does not yet qualify for a compact, the president has made improvement on the indicators a national priority and appointed the vice president to lead the effort. Aid programs are sustainable only when they are designed and carried out by the country that needs them. The Millennium Challenge Corporation insists on playing a robust consulting role to ensure that any program the United States helps finance has a good rate of return and a clear effect on reducing poverty, and that the highest standards of accounting are followed. But it also requires that poor countries assume primary responsibility for their own development to ensure that our assistance truly helps the poor help themselves. The corporation's board includes key members of the president's cabinet -- the secretaries of state and Treasury, the United States trade representative and the administrator of the United States Agency for International Development -- along with a bipartisan group of four citizens appointed by the president on the advice of Congress.
