Tonya Putnam is an assistant professor at the Department of Political Science of Columbia University French banking giant BNP Paribas was just hit with an $8.9 billion fine resulting from a combined settlement with federal and state government agencies. The reason? Extraterritorial violations of U.S. laws that prohibit private banks anywhere in the world from using U.S. dollars to transact with Iran, Sudan, Syria and other states under U.S. sanction. The unprecedented size of this penalty, which stems from transactions with Sudanese companies between 2002 and 2007, is raising eyebrows on both sides of the Atlantic-along with European hackles. Especially galling to many, including finance journalist Felix Salmon, is that the laws BNP Paribas violated have little or nothing to do with protecting the international banking system. Instead, they exist to serve U.S. foreign policy goals of isolating politically recalcitrant regimes. France, like the United States, wants to prevent Iran from acquiring nuclear weapons, and both countries condemn the Sudanese government's brutal actions in Darfur. However, the U.S. and French governments differ on what to do about it. Consequently, U.S. efforts to force foreign banks to follow U.S. policies instead of those of their own governments are a source of foreign resentment ... and not only in France. So, who gets to decide which laws, if any, govern banks, corporations and other non-state entities whose activities affect multiple countries simultaneously? This is a question of growing importance as the world becomes more interdependent. The answer will not surprise you (spoiler alert: it's the exceptionally powerful states), but the scope and character of the mechanism might. Extraterritorial restrictions on dealings with political antagonists of the United States grab headlines. But they are far from the only examples of U.S. extraterritoriality. Other areas where the United States has a history of throwing its weight around using U.S. laws and institutions to regulate conduct outside U.S. borders include antitrust, securities, bankruptcy, trademark protection, anti-corruption efforts and human rights. Only a few states have any real capacity to enforce their own laws extraterritorially on a wide scale. Extraterritorial capacity, in this view, means using ties to a state's territory, markets and institutions to claim direct legal authority over conduct outside its borders. Because so many large enterprises have links to the United States, U.S. law has considerable reach. Banking is a prime example, since no large international bank can avoid dealing in U.S. currency. For private entities that fear becoming targets of U.S. extraterritorial regulation, the bite is this: The very ties that provide a basis (under U.S. law) for U.S. jurisdiction in the first place are often connected to assets that later can be seized to satisfy penalties for violations. Transnational actors thus disregard U.S. law at their peril. For this reason, the strategic ones invest heavily in figuring out when, where, and against whom U.S. law might be brought to bear. The motivation is often to evade U.S. law. Even so, the threat of U.S. enforcement affects behavior, keeping it closer to the U.S. ideal than it would otherwise be. This is because selective market avoidance, complex corporate structures, and arms-length models of control provide only so much insulation against U.S. extraterritoriality. Even highly sophisticated entities at times fail to anticipate how U.S. authorities will interpret the scope of U.S. law, and what it requires. They can also miscalculate U.S. enforcement priorities, or the incentives of other private entities to sue in U.S. courts. All of this, in turn, enables the U.S. government to maintain policies that may be quite unpopular internationally. Notable examples include long-standing U.S. trade sanctions against Cuba, and strict U.S. rules against horizontal market collusion among private firms. Do options exist for countering unwelcome instances of U.S. extraterritoriality? Foreign governments have long tried to find ways to restrain the United States with limited success. One emerging possibility for checking U.S. assertiveness is reciprocal actions from the European Union, which now rivals the United States in the size of its internal market. As David Bach and Abraham Newman show, Europe is already well aware that it can leverage trade access to incentivize outsiders to adopt European standards in areas ranging from product specifications to data privacy. However, Europeans have shown few signs of mirroring U.S. extraterritorial practices. The reasons why are complex, but significant. First, Europeans have long been critical of U.S.-style jurisdictional unilateralism and often underscore its poor fit with international law. Second, regulatory enforcement in Europe is still largely the job of public officials, whereas in the United States private litigants can directly initiate extraterritorial enforcement of many U.S. public laws using domestic courts. Sometimes this entails simply doubling down on those already convicted of criminal violations with further suits for private damages. (Europe is only now beginning to experiment with this type of private enforcement in the competition law arena.) However, it is also common in the U.S. system for private litigants to independently select when, where, and against whom U.S. regulatory authority will be directed, even when this creates problems for U.S. foreign policy. This is not to suggest that U.S. courts do the bidding of just any plaintiff, American or foreign, that seeks to have U.S. law enforced extraterritorially. Far from it. Figuring out when U.S. courts have applied U.S. laws extraterritorially, when not, and why it matters for international affairs is the subject of my book (nearing completion) as well as my 2009 article in International Organization. The Department of Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC), has engaged in a recent fining frenzy. Coupled with the U.S. Supreme Court's approval last week of broad extraterritorial discovery of Argentina's foreign assets to enforce repayment of defaulted bonds, this might suggest a new wave of American legal aggressiveness. However, my research suggests it is actually becoming more difficult to get U.S. federal courts to interpret the extraterritorial reach of ambiguous U.S. laws expansively. This is evident in decisions handed down over the last decade in issues ranging from human rights to securities regulation. This reticence may be a sign of waning U.S. hegemony, or the product of dynamics internal to the U.S. judiciary - or both. What is clear is that a growing coterie of textual literalists on the Supreme Court is doing more to reel in U.S. extraterritoriality using a judicially constructed "presumption against extraterritoriality"_than have decades of foreign criticism Mugabe Urged to Reopen College  The closing of the University of Zimbabwe by the Government last week has led to a chorus of outrage here, and President Robert Mugabe's Government has responded to the dismay with further measures to stifle dissent. The university was closed indefinitely last Wednesday after students rioted and threw stones at the police. All 8,000 students were ordered off the campus in suburban Harare and all grants and scholarships were suspended. The Government announced that it would press charges against nearly 40 students arrested by the police on Wednesday. The students are still in custody, and there is no word on when the university, the only one in the country, might reopen. Church figures, professors, opposition politicians and union leaders have all called for the Government to reopen the university and to adopt a more conciliatory attitude toward the students. But such appeals appear to have had little effect in softening the official stand. On Friday, the Government arrested the Secretary General of the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions, Morgan Tsvangirai, after he issued a strongly worded condemnation of the university shutdown and voiced support for the students. Emergency Powers Criticized The document criticized the Government's use of emergency powers to arrest student leaders. The sweeping emergency powers were created in 1965 by the white minority Government to stamp out black nationalism. The powers give the Government the ability to detain an individual indefinitely without trial. The union statement said the continued use of the emergency powers by the Mugabe Government was a ''clear manifestation of rising state repression . . . against women, university lecturers, workers and trade unionists.'' Mr. Tsvangirai was taken from the trade union offices in handcuffs by three plainclothes policemen. The police are also holding two student leaders whose arrests early Wednesday set off a clash between stone-throwing students and policemen firing tear gas. A meeting of bishops from the Catholic, Anglican and other leading churches met last Thursday to discuss the incident and urged the Government to reopen the university. The campus troubles started over an attempt to hold a seminar on Sept. 29 to mark the first anniversary of student anti-corruption riots, which led to a judicial inquiry into official corruption early this year, bringing about the resignation of five Cabinet ministers.

Nigeria's new military ruler named a politically diverse Cabinet today that includes allies of the apparent winner of the presidential election in June. The Cabinet of 32 ministers is to be sworn in on Saturday, a Government statement said. Although no portfolios were stated on the Cabinet list, political analysts said the line-up was probably the most experienced since independence from Britain 33 years ago. "This list is like a Who's Who of Nigeria's contemporary politics," one political commentator said. Absent from the list was the apparent winner in June, Moshood Abiola, who has kept a low profile since the interim government was taken over last week. Today Mr. Abiola criticized the return of the military, but said he was not calling on his supporters to rise up against it. But he said the election results should be allowed to stand. Mr. Abiola was leading in the vote when it was annulled by General Babangida, plunging Nigeria into its worst political crisis since the Biafra civil war of 1967-70. Among those named to the Cabinet were Iyorchia Ayu, former leader of the Senate and an ally of Mr. Abiola as well as his running mate, Baba Gana Kingibe, who has been named Foreign Minister. It also includes members of the last Cabinet, former Oil Minister Don Etiebet, who began an anti-corruption crusade at the Nigerian National Petroleum Corporation in September, and former Finance Minister Aminu Saleh. General Abacha justified his takeover as necessary to save Nigeria from collapse. And 24 hours after taking charge, he banned politics and dismantled all political institutions. The general, who is Nigeria's seventh military ruler, has been an influential member of every administration since the last democratic government was toppled by the military in 1983. He has yet to announce any political program but has pledged that the military will not stay in power long. On Wednesday, the military government installed a Provisional Ruling Council, of which General Abacha is chairman and Defense Minister.

For Willis Juma, the decision to vote against the governing party in Kenya's presidential election on Monday comes down to his aching back. Though he has a degree in accounting, the only job Mr. Juma could find after college was part-time work lifting sacks of coffee for about $3 a day. He lives in a shantytown where there are no paved roads or sewers and where a cholera epidemic is raging. "We are being suppressed by the Government in so many ways," Mr. Juma, 25, said Saturday at a rally here for an opposition candidate. "You can't get a job unless you are politically correct. We are paying a lot of money in taxes, but if you go to the hospital you can't get even those simple tablets like aspirin." Like many Kenyans, Mr. Juma blames years of official corruption and mismanagement under President Daniel arap Moi for his situation. For two decades, Mr. Moi, 74, and his party have run this once prosperous former British colony with a mixture of graft and mismanagement. But even though a majority of the nine million Kenyans registered to vote are expected to cast their ballots for opposition candidates, Mr. Moi is still favored to win the election, because he faces 13 challengers deeply divided along ethnic lines, diplomats and analysts say. In 1991 Mr. Moi reluctantly bowed to heavy international pressure and ended the monopoly on power held by his party, the Kenya African National Union. But Kenya's first multiparty elections, in 1992, were marred by ethnic clashes in the Rift Valley, a Moi political stronghold. Hundreds of people were killed and tens of thousands were displaced as supporters of Mr. Moi, who is from the Kalejin minority, attacked people from large ethnic groups who supported other candidates. Opposition candidates also faced enormous obstacles in 1992. The Government-owned radio and television stations ignored their campaigns, while local officials loyal to Mr. Moi harassed opposition leaders at every turn, barring them from entering the President's political strongholds. At the same time, the governing party printed money and used it to buy votes in the hinterlands, international election observers said. Despite these advantages, Mr. Moi drew only 37 percent of the vote. He won anyway, largely because the opposition was so divided that it could not agree on a single challenger. This year, violent pro-democracy protests over the summer and harsh criticism from industrialized countries that provide economic aid again compelled Mr. Moi to agree to political reforms. In October his party repealed several laws that allowed the President to jail opponents and ban opposition parties. The reforms also barred local officials and the police from taking part in politics, expanded the electoral commission to include opposition representatives and ordered the Government news media to give equal time to challengers. Days after the reforms were passed, Mr. Moi announced a three-week campaign to be waged in the Christmas season, insuring that his opponents would have little time to take advantage of the new political playing field. Mr. Moi's most formidable challenger is a former Vice President, Mwai Kibaki, an economist and political insider with strong support from Kenya's largest ethnic group, the Kikuyu. Mr. Kibaki has promised to stamp out corruption, revive the economy and give every child a free primary education. Another strong challenger is Charity Ngilu, a businesswoman and member of Parliament from the relatively small Akamba group. She has positioned herself as a compromise candidate for people who are disenchanted with Mr. Moi but still suspicious of candidates from the larger groups like Mr. Kibaki. "I realized that opposition leaders were never going to unite, never going to allow Kenyans that one single candidate," she told reporters recently. "So I created that alternative leader Kenyans were looking for." For the last three weeks, the opposition candidates have scrambled around the country by car, preaching to small crowds at roadsides and in parking lots, looking for the right oratorical formula to dislodge one of Africa's longest-serving presidents. Mr. Moi, meanwhile, has taken full advantage of his office, traveling from town to town in his presidential jet. His speeches are attended by the trappings of power -- police bands, choirs, crowds of schoolchildren singing his praises and thousands of loyal party members, some of whom are paid to attend. But the President's tone has changed since 1992. At a recent rally, he railed about Kenya's bad roads and poor hospitals as if he were a political outsider. Where he once imperiously ordered supporters to vote for him and threatened to crush opponents with force, he is now begging for understanding and support. "I'm asking you to vote for me," he said, holding up his trademark ivory and gold scepter. "If you know I will make some contribution or I have played my part in contributing toward the development of Kenya, vote for me." But that development is hard to see. Per capita income has fallen from $700 at independence in 1963 to about $270 now. Economic growth this year will be less than 2 percent. About four million college and high school graduates do not have jobs. One recent study placed the gap between rich and poor here second only to that in Brazil. Power and water shortages are common even in Nairobi, the capital. The roads, neglected for years, are falling apart. Even the main highway from the port of Mombasa to Nairobi is nearly impassable in places. It is a country where most of the 28 million people buy their clothes used and live in slums without running water, where people sleep two to a bed in the capital's best public hospital, where most college graduates take menial jobs or remain unemployed for years. "Young people like me, you go to school, you go to training, you get out and you don't get employment," said Juma Nassur, 34, an unemployed auto mechanic who supports Raila Odinga, a young liberal member of Parliament. "Our Government is corrupt." Among the oppposition candidates, Mr. Kibaki, who was a top member of Mr. Moi's Cabinet until 1992, has cast himself as an anti-corruption crusader. On the hustings, he accuses Mr. Moi and his cronies of stealing millions from development projects. Over and over, he hammers the themes of stolen tax money, bad roads and poorly stocked hospitals. "This Government is full of thieves," Mr. Kibaki told a crowd of about 10,000 supporters today in Uhuru Park in Nairobi. "The taxes you pay are enough to fix the roads. They are enough to buy medicine, to do repairs to the hospitals, to pay doctors and nurses, to educate primary school students." But it is Ms. Ngilu's campaign that has generated the most excitement. Having served only one term in Parliament, the 45-year-old bakery owner and restaurateur is seen by many as a fresh face in politics, untainted by scandal. She has promised to serve just five years, to stanch bribery and rewrite the Constitution to give less power to the President. Her campaign has attracted many women across ethnic lines, as well as underemployed young men and middle-class Ken yans who are tired of the old-school politicians. By and large, the campaigning has gone ahead with little interference from the police or local officials, diplomats say. The election, in which 210 parliamentary seats are also at stake, is one of the most scrutinized in Kenya's history. Financed by $2.5 million from foreign donors, Kenyan church organizations have deployed more than 840 monitors to watch the campaigners on the road and more than 27,000 poll watchers to go to voting sites on Monday. "Generally the situation is much better than it was in 1992," Sam Kabue, a church official who heads the campaign monitoring group said. "There is less intimidation and more freedom for people to go out and say what they want." Even if there is no election rigging, none of the challengers have a chance of winning on the first ballot, analysts said. Mr. Moi's coalition of smaller ethnic groups, who would fear a Kikuyu or Luo as President, appears to be holding together, while the other main candidates lack strong support outside their own groups. But the opposition does has a slim hope of forcing a runoff election. That is because an unusual electoral rule requires the leading vote-getter to garner at least a quarter of the votes in five of the country's eight provinces or face a runoff with the second-place candidate. Mr. Moi won easily in the first round in 1992, when he made a respectable showing in the Akamba and the Luhyia communities. But Ms. Ngilu's candidacy may make it hard for Mr. Moi to get a quarter of the votes in the Eastern Province, where her Akamba group is the majority, and Mr. Wamalwa could lock him out of the Western Province, where his Luyhia are the majority. With two other provinces already expected to go to opposition candidates, this is a scenario Mr. Moi wants to avoid. A runoff might unite the anti-Moi vote behind the second-place candidate. And even if Mr. Moi wins the election as expected, the fundamental problems facing his Government are not about to go away. Neither is the unhappiness among the working and middle classes. "The Government is out of touch with the feelings of the common man," said John Mbugua, a Ngilu supporter who sells electrical goods from a street stall in Nairobi. "Under the present Government, it has completely collapsed. We don't even have roads you can talk about. "Sometimes I feel hopeless. Saying I feel sad is not enough. We are drifting toward the unknown."

Kenya was thrown into a political crisis today after officials extended the presidential election to a second day because of widespread logistical problems. Opposition leaders immediately accused the Government of trying to rig the voting. Many polling places were so swamped with crowds of frustrated voters at 6 this evening, when polls were supposed to close, that the Kenya Electoral Commission ordered a second day of voting, raising questions about how the Government would safeguard ballot boxes overnight. The decision fanned fears among opposition candidates that the governing party was going to stuff ballot boxes to insure a fifth term for President Daniel arap Moi, the 74-year-old strongman who has been in power in Kenya since 1978. Some presidential candidates threatened to reject the election results and take to the streets unless the ballot boxes were kept in under guard in polling places overnight. They also demanded that election officials begin at once to count ballots in constituencies where no problems were reported. "The election commission has been infiltrated and is being manipulated by the Government with the intention of distorting the results of this election," Mwai Kibaki, the Democratic Party's candidate, said tonight. Election officials declined to comment on these accusations, though they acknowledged that the voting had been hampered by bad weather, delays and confusion. Floods prevented voting in much of northeastern Kenya, where some residents tried to paddle boats to their polling stations. Some polling places did not receive enough presidential ballots for all of their registered voters. In other places, the ballots were delivered late or sent to the wrong locations, causing three- and four-hour delays in the opening of polls. The accusations of vote-rigging came at the end of a chaotic day in which millions of Kenyans walked for miles and stood in line for hours to vote. In most of the country, the voting was more peaceful than many people had predicted. Two people were reported killed in political violence today, far fewer than the hundreds who died in ethnic clashes leading up to the 1992 election. A small riot broke out in the town of Ngong when Mr. Moi's Vice President, George Saitoti, who represents the area and is facing a tough re-election campaign, arrived at a polling station with several extra ballot boxes. No one was hurt in the fracas, but just after 7:15 the police fired in the air to disperse the crowd, which had stoned Mr. Saitoti's car and burned the extra ballot boxes, a witness said. Mr. Moi is unpopular with most Kenyans because rampant official corruption and inept management in his administration have deeply eroded this once prosperous country's economy over the last two decades, diplomats and political experts say. Still, Mr. Moi was expected to win the election, largely because he still can pull about 40 percent of the vote and faces a field of 12 challengers (as well as two who have dropped out but are still on the ballot) deeply divided along ethnic lines. Unable to agree on a single challenger, the opposition's sole hope for victory lay in forcing a runoff, which might unite the anti-Moi vote behind the second-place candidate. The problems at the polls today, however, have given opposition leaders ammunition for their charge that Mr. Moi is trying to steal the election.  Some challengers were already predicting violence if Mr. Moi is re-elected. One was Charity Ngilu, a 45-year-old member of Parliament and businesswoman whose anti-corruption message has attracted many Kenyans. She has asserted that Mr. Moi's agents have tried to buy votes in her home district of Kitui and are paying her supporters to give up their voting cards. She maintained that she had found evidence to support her claims -- about 400 voter cards hidden in a bottom desk drawer of the local election officer -- after she and her backers stormed the election commissions offices in Kitui this morning. The officer denied any wrongdoing, saying the cards had not been bought but were duplicates made for people who had lost the originals. "If Moi wins, we will not allow him to take over," Ms. Ngilu said later. "If he wins, it's going to be very difficult for him to manage. Kenyans are very angry and I will incite my people. People in other places will also incite their people." Mr. Kibaki, the former Vice President and a top contender, said tonight that the election commission had deliberately sent too few presidential ballots to his strongholds to hamper the voting. For instance, the district of Gagaki, on the slopes of Mount Kenya, he said, the polling station received only 400 ballots for President, when it has 4,000 registered voters. More ballots were delivered after a five-hour delay. The same thing happened in at least 29 other constituencies where the opposition is strong, he said. "We know it could not have been an accident," he said. In Nairobi, several polling stations opened three or four hours late because ballots had not been delivered on time and poll officials were unprepared. At a primary school in the Westlands area, for instance, people stood in lines two city blocks long and waited for three hours just to get into the polling station. Despite the long lines, most voters did not give up. Many said the election was too important to their futures to abandon their rights just because of a long wait under a hot sun. "I'm exercising my democratic right to vote," said Richard Wanjohi, 40, a contractor, who had been in line for three hours. "I really want to see that I have a change in the Government." But in other parts of Kenya, which has 28 million residents divided among 42 ethnic groups, the voting went off without a hitch. The atmosphere was much less tense than in 1992, when ethnic clashes at voting places and intimidation by soldiers and the police was common. In Kajiado, for instance, a Rift Valley town 40 miles south of the capital, long lines of Masai men and women, dressed in traditional garb, voted peacefully while election monitors watched. Each polling station had only three soldiers, who generally kept a low profile. More than half of the voters in Kajiado were illiterate, however, election officials said. They were shown which box to mark on the ballot while representatives from all the parties watched. Several of the Masai said they still supported Mr. Moi, despite the corruption and lack of Government services in the region. They said they were afraid that a president from one of the larger tribes, like the Kikuyu or Luo, would do even less for them. Mr. Moi comes from the small Tugen subgroup of the Kalenjin tribe. "Moi is not a bad man, but it is his servants who are bad," said Olerisa Leintoy, a 40-year-old Masai woman. "Because we are a small tribe we have to support Moi." Forty miles to the northeast, in Machakos, a stronghold of Ms. Ngilu's Akamba tribe, hundreds of voters waited for three hours under a blistering sun to cast their votes at a station in the Machakos Show Grounds. Many said they supported Ms. Ngilu and believed that she could clean up the Government, because she was a relative newcomer to politics, untainted by graft. "We just hope for a total change, a reversal of the trends," said Josiah Musyoka, a 41-year-old furniture maker. "I think everybody is really fed up now."

Kenya's general election degenerated into confusion today as both President Daniel arap Moi and opposition candidates accused the beleaguered Kenyan Electoral Commission of rigging the election against them. As polls finally closed this afternoon after a unexpected second day of voting and the counting of ballots slowly got under way, politicians on all sides were already laying the groundwork for rejecting the results. In a statement read on the state radio, President Moi accused the 21-member commission of involvement "in a scheme to rig the ongoing general elections in favor of the opposition." His statement came a day after three leading opposition candidates asserted that the electoral commission had deliberately sent too few ballots to opposition strongholds to hinder voting. Questions about the election raised fears among many Kenyans and diplomats that there might be a resurgence of political violence. Pro-democracy protests took 12 lives and rocked this country's economy last summer. "You have a situation where whoever loses is going to have the ability to say the process has been rigged," said a diplomat who insisted on anonymity. "The question now is how many people are going to scream, and how loudly and what else will they do?" The election pits Mr. Moi, 74, who has been President since 1978, against more than a dozen challengers who are divided along tribal lines. The President, whose administration has been marked by corruption and a crumbling economy, was expected to win a fifth term narrowly with about 40 percent of the vote because the anti-incumbent vote is so splintered, political experts said. But the polling on Monday descended into chaos in many parts of this East African country because of bad weather, logistical problems, mismanagement and disorganization among local election officials. Late Monday night, with crowds of frustrated voters still waiting for ballots at many of the 13,600 polling stations, the commission extended the voting by a day. Today, more reports of irregularities filtered into the capital from across the country even as voting continued in some regions and ballot counting started in places where the polling had gone smoothly on Monday. There were widespread instances in which ballots were sent to the wrong polling stations. In many cases, there were too few presidential ballots for the number of registered voters. Some polling stations in the Rift Valley did not open until 3 in the afternoon for lack of ballots. Some in western Kenya did not open at all on Monday. There were also numerous reports of violence between various political factions, vote-buying outside polling stations, the buying and destruction of voter cards, missing ballot boxes, intimidation, and in at least one district, burned ballot boxes and destroyed ballots. Worried that the voting would be rigged to give Mr. Moi a victory, many party workers spent the night guarding ballot boxes in polling stations and vote-counting locations across the country. Although the official election observers from foreign embassies and church groups had not finished compiling their reports, some diplomats and political experts estimated that at least a quarter of the country's 210 parliamentary constituencies were affected by the irregularities. But they added that many of the problems had been rectified on the second day of polling, and it did not appear that the irregularities would skew the election results. The political damage, however, had already been done by the allegations of rigging, they said. Gabriel K. Mukele, the vice chairman of the election commission, said most of the problems had resulted from mistakes made by the company in England that had printed the ballots. He said that in some cases the printer had packed ballot books in the wrong crates, causing them to be sent to the wrong constituencies. Mr. Mukele also acknowledged that local election officials had made errors, often sending the wrong number of presidential ballots to polling stations. He denied charges, however, that the election commission, which has representatives from both the governing party and the opposition, had created the problems to hurt one candidate or another. "Some officers did not do the distribution properly," he said. "What is not true is that the ballots were sent in small quantities selectively to favor one candidate." For security reasons, Mr. Mukele said the ballots were shipped to Kenya from England just days before the election and the crates were not opened until the night before the polling. This was done at election headquarters in far-flung districts. As a result, election officers did not discover until a few hours before the polls were to open that many ballots had been misdirected. In addition, he said, heavy flooding and muddy roads had hampered the distribution of ballots in less developed parts of the country, like the Rift Valley and the northeast. Helicopters were used to ferry the ballots to those areas today, he said. Kenya is the size of Texas and has 28 million inhabitants. Defending the commission's work, Mr. Mukele said the irregularities affected only about 5 percent of the constituencies and "are not serious enough to lead to considering these elections as faulty in my view." He said the mix-ups in delivering ballot papers had been remedied today. "There is suspicion in Kenya," he said. "And our politics are ethnically based. Everyone wants to be at the top. Allegations come very early. Anything that someone might imagine might happen is put out to everyone as a fact." "The politicians don't trust one another," he added, "and they make wild allegations for the consumption of the simple people and they are taken as fact by their tribal followers." But Kenyan election observers and pro-democracy advocates disagreed vehemently. A statement by election observers said there had been "major shortcomings in the voting exercise," while the main pro-democracy advocacy group that organized the demonstrations last summer called the election "irredeemably flawed" and a "fantastic farce." The top presidential challengers, meanwhile, continued to cry foul. "Moi has rigged the process as he did in 1992, just that this time round he will not fool anybody," Raila Odinga, the candidate for the National Development Party, told Reuters. "We are prepared for him, and we are ready to take him head on." The atmosphere was tense at counting stations in Nairobi and Machakos today, as election officials began going through the ballots by hand with hundreds of party loyalists and riot police officers crowded around outside the stations. It was slow going. For instance, it took more than two hours this morning and several shouting matches to count the first ballot box for the presidential race in Nairobi City Hall. There were 371 other boxes stacked up at one end of the hall. The ballots were sorted into piles by a dozen clerks while angry party representatives scowled at them and objected several times. "By tomorrow we should be through," said Jane Karanja, a weary election official in charge of the counting. "I'm praying for that." In the town of Machakos, about 40 miles south of the capital, people were edgy at the Machakos Social Hall, where counting began this morning. The town is a stronghold of Charity Ngilu, the 45-year-old businesswoman and political newcomer whose anti-corruption message threatened to break Mr. Moi's hold on the Eastern Province. A crowd of 200 Ngilu supporters waited outside hall for news while officials dumped out the paper ballots on tables in front of party agents and went through them. Each time a box showed a majority for Mr. Moi, an angry murmur rose from the crowd. "Tell them if they are stealing votes, we will burn this place down!" shouted Kioko Maundu, a 24-year-old unemployed man. "They are thieves."

Bob Astles, once an aide to the dictator Idi Amin, was freed today after six years in prison. Mr. Astles, a Briton who came to Uganda in 1949, was head of Mr. Amin's anti-corruption squad before the regime was deposed in 1979. He also held Ugandan citizenship but renounced it to obtain his release.

COUNTRY: TANZANIA, UNITED REPUBLIC OF (95%); AFRICA (93%); KENYA (92%); EASTERN AFRICA (79%);
TEXT: Nyamata, Rwanda The white altar cloth in the Catholic Church of Nyamata is still stained brown with blood. Shoes, dresses and trousers worn by families massacred within the sanctuary lie, gently decaying, atop the pews. The hole in the church's iron door, blown open years ago by a grenade, will never be repaired: The Catholic Church of Nyamata is now a museum, a memorial to the thousands of people murdered here in April 1994, at the peak of the Rwandan genocide. When I stepped outside, I could hear a congregation singing: A new church has been built next door. Around the corner, I could hear children in their classrooms, hard at work on a Saturday. Along the road to Kigali, the Rwandan capital, trees have been planted. Development economists and aid mavens know very well the story of Rwanda's remarkable recovery. But the country's achievements may be less appreciated by the wider public. Seventeen years after more than 800,000 ethnic Tutsis were murdered in just a few months by their Hutu neighbors, Rwanda has 7 percent economic growth, near-universal health insurance and fierce anti-corruption laws. Kigali is remarkably clean and relatively safe. Some 40 percent of Rwandans own cellphones. National identity cards now identify people as "Rwandan," not Hutu or Tutsi. It is the ambition of Paul Kagame, the Rwandan president - and former leader of the Tutsi exile army that conquered the country in the genocide's wake - to go much further. While visiting one Rwandan government agency I accidentally picked up some notes left by previous visitors, an advisory team from Singapore. Their presence was no accident: Lee Kwan Yew's benign authoritarianism is widely admired here, and some of his methods are in evident use. The former Singaporean leader infamously banned chewing gum in his country. Kagame has banned plastic bags - they aren't biodegradeable - and requires all Rwandans to wear shoes. But there are limits to copying the Singaporean model. Rwanda is landlocked, and it has difficult neighbors. A truck leaving Kigali takes at least four days to reach Mombasa, Kenya, the nearest port. Worse, the driver will pay, according to one survey, $864 in bribes at 36 roadblocks along the way. Much though it might like to be an export-led African tiger, Rwanda's geography prevents it. Rwanda's government has, as a result, set an ambitious goal: to become a "services hub" for central Africa or, in the local jargon, a "knowledge- and information-based economy." Toward that end, the government has begun laying fiber-optic cable across the country and has been vigorously courting foreign investors (Mexican tycoon Carlos Slim was in town just a few days ago). And here is where Rwanda's ambitious economic plans run into Rwanda's political reality. Though some opposition is legal, and though people in the capital speak openly about the country's deficits, the Rwandan press is weak and journalists are downtrodden. Some have been murdered. Others are in jail. Many have fled the country. All are considered fair game for bullying, and not only by the government. One journalist showed me an e-mail he received from a local nongovernmental organization that wanted him to publish a photograph. Its conclusion: "Please post the picture online and if not, please give a clear explanation as to why not." Until now, Kagame and his ministers have argued - citing the track record in Singapore and elsewhere - that control of the press, of politics and of speech was essential to the preservation of what still seems, to them, a fragile peace. Their fear of destructive criticism - and of losing power - is not excusable, but it is understandable, given their history: The current political elite is largely composed of members of the Tutsi minority who with Kagame fought their way back into the country in 1994, where they found piles of corpses. Supporters of the old regime live across the border in Congo, or so current leaders believe, and still write angry denunciations of the regime from their exile. And yet no government that prohibits the free circulation of information can create a "knowledge- and information-based economy." Even leaving aside the ethics, nobody will invest in a "services hub" where people fear speaking the truth. Some of Rwanda's leaders at the very highest levels know this and are pushing broad media reforms; I was in Rwanda with the Legatum Institute  - a London-based nonpartisan group devoted to good governance, for which I am director of political studies - to learn about these changes. The Rwandans still have a long way to go, as they themselves will acknowledge. But they may have no choice, for there is a larger point here: In recent years, it has become fashionable in some circles to speak of a "Beijing consensus," a road to growth and development that eschews democracy, scorns Western models and favors authoritarianism, benign or otherwise. A few years back, Rwandans leapt onto this bandwagon too. It got them a clean capital, fast growth and low crime - quite far, in other words. But how much farther? The development economists and aid mavens often speak of the "bottlenecks" in infrastructure and energy supply that might block growth in Rwanda. Maybe it's time to add "lack of free speech" to that list. applebaumletters@washpost.com The global discontent  What's intriguing about the eruption of Occupy Wall Street is that it's so similar to other populist movements that are demanding change in nearly every major region of the world. You can't help but wonder if we aren't seeing, as a delayed reaction to the financial crisis of 2008, a kind of "global spring" of discontent. Obviously, circumstances differ: The anti-corporate activists gathered in Manhattan's Zuccotti Park  have a different agenda  than the demonstrators in Cairo's  Tahrir Square, or this past summer's rioting street protesters in Britain and Greece, or the anti-corruption marchers in New Delhi. These movements mostly lack leaders or clear ideologies, so they're hard to categorize. But the protesters do share some basics: rejection of traditional political elites; a belief that "globalization" benefits the rich more than the masses; anger about intertwined business and political corruption; and the connectedness and empowerment fostered by Facebook and other social media. This neo-populism is all the more striking because it seems to transcend traditional political boundaries. The Tea Party movement may wear conservative colors, but it arose as a protest against elites in Washington and on Wall Street who were seen to be profiting at the expense of everyday people. Occupy Wall Street comes at these same issues from the left, but the two movements have much in common. The Arab Spring is the world's most potent populist movement, sweeping away governments in Tunisia, Egypt and Libya. These uprisings began as leaderless explosions of indignation - blurring the usual lines of capitalist and socialist, Muslim and Christian. These cleavages have returned, especially in Egypt. But the core of the revolution there remains a rage against traditional elites. Protests in Europe have the same note of mass indignation. In Greece, Italy and even France, you see the anger of the middle class that their debt-enfeebled governments can't deliver on welfare-state promises. In some countries, such as Britain and Germany, there is unrest, too, among growing immigrant populations that are not tethered to national cultural or political norms. Even in the boom countries, such as China and India, there is the turmoil that comes with rising expectations. According to China's Ministry of Public Security, the country experienced 87,000 incidents of popular unrest in 2005. That's 238 protests a day! The Chinese stopped publishing the number after that, but it surely hasn't gone down. India, too, has seen a rising tide of protest, symbolized by the mass street marches in the summer that surrounded Anna Hazare's hunger strike to protest corruption. It's a stretch, perhaps, to look for shared themes in such disparate countries. But these movements seem to have a common indignation toward leaders who are failing to maintain social justice along with global economic change. That's certainly true in America, where the Tea Party and Occupy Wall Street both rage against a financial elite that stumbled into a ruinous recession - and then got bailed out by a Washington elite that's in hock to special interests. The Tea Party, especially, tapped the bedrock American mistrust of big banks, which dates to Thomas Jefferson and Andrew Jackson. Growth and prosperity would restore public confidence, as in the past. But this time, the anticipated recovery - and deflation of popular anger - still seems a few years away. Europe's neo-populism will surely increase, as countries struggle with painful economic adjustments. Population is declining in most of Europe, which means there will be fewer young workers to pay for the pensions of retirees. To regain competitiveness and solvency, wages and the quality of life will have to decline in many European countries. Meanwhile, according to a recent study by the National Intelligence Council, by 2025              Western Europe's Muslim population could increase to 25 million to 30 million from the current 15 million to 18 million, causing  additional strains. There's no sign yet of a new European political leadership that can accomplish the necessary rewrite of the social contract. Much of the world's neo-populist anger is justified, given the greed and folly of recent years. What worries me is the echo of the 1930s, a similar period of economic change and dislocation. When the traditional business and political leaders seemed to have failed during the downturn of the '30s, populist indignation veered sharply right and left - toward dangerous movements that expressed national indignation at the point of a gun. America was lucky then to have had, in President Franklin D. Roosevelt, a charismatic politician who could rehabilitate the center. And now? Not so lucky. davidignatius@washpost.com  Egypt          Mubarak sons saidto have $340 million The two sons of ousted president Hosni Mubarak have an estimated $340 million in Swiss bank accounts, a senior Egyptian Justice Ministry official said Monday. Assem al-Gohary said Swiss authorities are investigating whether one of the sons, Alaa, was involved in money laundering along with other regime figures. At home, Mubarak and his sons have been charged with corruption and are under arrest. Mubarak also is charged with complicity in the killing ofabout 850 protesters during theJan. 25-Feb. 11 Egyptian uprising. Switzerland has already frozen the assets of the Mubarak family and other former regime figures, which Gohary estimated at nearly $450 million. In Egypt, the attorney general froze the assets of the former presidential family on Feb. 20. - Associated Press Mexico          61 freed captiveswere migrants Mexican President Felipe Calderon said Monday that 61 men who had been kidnapped by a drug cartel before soldiers rescued them were migrants. Calderon said kidnappers working for the Zetas drug cartel were holding the men captive in the northern border city of Piedras Negras until their families paid a ransom. Soldiers found the men Saturday at a safe house guarded by three of the alleged kidnappers. Federal prosecutors say cartel workers intercepted the migrants outside a bus station in Piedras Negras and lured them to go with them by falsely offering to take them into the United States for charges ranging from $600 to $3,000. - Associated Press Venezuela          Opposition leader faces new obstacle Venezuela's Supreme Court threw into doubt the presidential campaign of a prominent opposition leader Monday by upholding a ban on his holding office. The Supreme Court ruled as "impracticable" a decision issued last month by the Costa Rica-based Inter-American Court of Human Rights that demanded that Venezuelan electoral officials allow Leopoldo Lopez to run for office. Lopez was on a list of politicians blacklisted because of corruption probes, but he insists he is innocent and notes that he was never sentenced in a court. The former Caracas district mayor was barred from holding office by Venezuela's top anti-corruption official starting in 2008. The temporary prohibition resulted from allegations that a nonprofit group that Lopez led had received donations from 1998 to 2001 from state oil company Petroleos de Venezuela, where his mother worked. The comptroller general also sanctioned Lopez in 2004 for alleged irregularities in the movement of funds from one portion of his local budget to another. - Associated Press Judge chosen as Jordan's prime minister:King Abdullah II designated a well-known international judge as his prime minister Monday, a royal palace statement said, replacing a premier who ran afoul of reformers. Awn al-Khasawneh succeeds Marouf al-Bakhit, who resigned earlier in the day after 70 of 120 parliament members urged his ouster. Libyan fighters celebrate capture of Bani Walid: Fighters with Libya's interim government fired guns into the air and hoisted the country's new flag over the center of Bani Walid on Monday to celebrate their capture of one of the final bastions of Moammar Gaddafi's loyalists. A Reuters team that drove into Bani Walid, in desert hills about 100 miles southeast of Tripoli, saw no signs of resistance from loyalists. Chile drafts thousands into military: Chile is giving nearly 57,000 18-year-olds one month to report for potential military duty, saying it needs to fill gaps in its armed forces because a student protest movement has reduced the number of volunteers. Military service is obligatory in Chile, but there are usually enough volunteers so that no one has to serve against their will. - From news services SEC charges oil executives with bribing officials in Nigeria  Federal regulators have charged a former chief executive of the Swiss oil services company Noble and two other executives with bribing Nigerian government officials to get permits for drilling rigs in that country. The Securities and Exchange Commission charged the three executives Friday with violating the Foreign Corrupt Practices Act from 2003 through 2007. They are former chief executive Mark Jackson, former controller and head of internal audits Thomas O'Rourke, and James Ruehlen, who is the director and division manager of Noble's Nigerian subsidiary. O'Rourke settled the charges by agreeing to pay a $35,000 fine. He neither admitted nor denied wrongdoing. Jackson and Ruehlen are disputing the charges. Noble, which has operations worldwide and an office in Sugar Land, Tex., was charged with criminal and civil foreign-bribery violations in November 2010 as part of what the government called a "sweep" of the oil services industry. The company cooperated with government investigators and wasn't prosecuted. It agreed to pay about $5.6 million in restitution and a $2.6 million criminal fine. The SEC's charges are the latest action in the government's efforts to combat overseas corruption in international business. A number of U.S. and foreign companies have been charged in recent years with violating the anti-corruption law, which makes it illegal to bribe foreign government officials or company executives to secure or retain business. In its lawsuit filed in Houston, the SEC said that Jackson and Ruehlen bribed Nigerian customs officials to process phony paperwork showing that Noble's oil rigs were moved in and out of the country even when they weren't. The purpose was to save the company substantial costs of exporting rigs from Nigeria and then re-importing them with new permits. O'Rourke helped approve the bribes and allowed the payments to be falsely recorded as legitimate operating expenses for Noble, according to the SEC. "These executives knowingly authorized and paid foreign officials to process false documents, and they consciously concealed the scheme from Noble's audit committee," Gerald Hodgkins, an associate director of the SEC's enforcement division, said in a statement. Jackson's attorney, David Krakoff, called the SEC's allegations "baseless." He said the former Noble chief executive "will vigorously defend himself in court, where the evidence will show what the SEC already knows, that at all times Mr. Jackson acted in good faith at Noble. "He looks forward to clearing his good name in this proceeding," Krakoff said in a statement. F. Joseph Warin, an attorney representing Ruehlen, said it was his client who initially raised the issue within the company. Ruehlen "fully cooperated throughout the investigation and always acted in an ethical and transparent manner," Warin's statement said. "The claims against Mr. Ruehlen are wrong and they will be proven so at trial." - Associated Press  Russia          Putin opponent winskey mayoral election An anti-corruption crusader has won a landslide victory in a mayoral election in a major Russian city, dealing a painful blow to the ruling party and energizing the beleaguered opposition. Yevgeny Urlashov won 70 percent of Sunday's vote in Yaroslavl, a city of about 590,000 some 150 miles east of Moscow, easily defeating the acting mayor, who was the candidate of president-elect Vladimir Putin's United Russia party. Urlashov's victory reflects growing public irritation with official corruption and social inequality. And it gives new hope to Russia's opposition, which has struggled to maintain momentum after Putin won a third presidential term last month. Opposition leaders have urged their supporters to focus on local elections, and Urlashov's victory is likely to bolster that strategy. Urlashov, a 45-year-old lawyer who was a member of the municipal council, won the race after a campaign heavily slanted in favor of his rival, who received blanket positive coverage from local television. Police also raided Urlashov's headquarters. - Associated Press Colombia          Guerrilla group frees 10 captives Colombia's main rebel group on Monday freed what it says were its last 10 military and police captives, returning the men to their families after at least 12 years spent in jungle prisons. The release of the six police officers and four soldiers highlighted efforts by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia to seek peace talks. It is Latin America's oldest and most potent guerrilla band, and it has been weakened by Colombia's U.S.-backed military. Flown to Bogota aboard a loaned Brazilian air force helicopter, the freed captives waved jubilantly. They were escorted from the helicopter by nurses to waiting relatives for reunions behind closed doors. Some jumped for joy on the runway. The Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia, known as FARC, had announced Monday's liberation on Feb. 26 in tandem with a halt in ransom kidnappings as a revenue source. - Associated Press Saudi Arabia          Girls may be allowedto play school sports Saudi Arabia is considering letting girls play sports at school, a senior education official was quoted as saying Monday, in what would represent a relaxation of rules governing women's lives in the conservative Islamic kingdom. Under Saudi Arabia's strict Islamic legal system, powerful clerics have issued religious rulings against female participation in sports. Women must receive the permission of a male "guardian" to travel abroad, work and have some elective surgery. They are also barred from driving. After King Abdullah moved last year to bring women into the country's political process, however, there have been some signs that authorities may allow sportswomen to compete internationally and make it easier for girls to exercise. - Reuters Mali          West African groupimposes sanctions The body representing West African nations on Monday imposed severe financial sanctions on Mali after a 72-hour deadline elapsed and soldiers who recently seized power in a coup failed to fully restore constitutional order. The Economic Community of West African States held an emergency meeting in the capital of Senegal on Monday. After the three-hour meeting, the chairman of the bloc, Ivory Coast President Alassane Ouattara, said the sanctions would go into effect immediately. They include the closing of the borders with Mali and the freezing of the nation's account in the regional central bank, measures that are likely to suffocate the economy of this poor and landlocked nation. Mali imports its petroleum products from neighboring Ivory Coast, and with the border closed, Mali is likely to run out of gasoline. But these are no ordinary tourists. Salwa Bugaighis and Amira Yahyaoui, two of nine female activists from around the world being feted in Washington this week, are deep in conversation about feminism and its frustrations in the aftermath of their countries' revolutions. Household names in their homelands, the dissidents - Bugaighis, one of the first women on Libya's transitional council, who resigned to protest the role's tokenism, and Yahyaoui, 27, Tunisia's leading anti-censorship blogger - will be honored Wednesday night at the Kennedy Center by the Vital Voices Global Partnership. The event is sort of  like the Oscars, but for the world's toughest women's rights activists.          Along with six other female leaders, Bugaighis and Yahyaoui are on a Sunday evening bus tour of Washington attractions. The sightseeing is meant to get the honorees - who have heard about one another on blogs or through Facebook but have not met - out of hotel conference halls and give them a little bonding time. And it seems to be working. Fast friends, the visitors talk about how - despite the fact that women and men stood hand in hand during the Arab Spring protests - men sidelined the women almost immediately afterward. "The question is how do we, as women, stand again?" said Shatha al-Harazi, a 26-year-old reporter for the Yemen Times who overheard the women from Libya and Tunisia. Al-Harazi, who has braces, could be mistaken for a teenager. But she was summoned to the presidential palace after her tweets called attention to Yemen's human rights abuses. She said that President Ali Abdullah Saleh should resign. "Since I was in the fifth grade, I have always been questioning things," Harazi said as the tour van rumbled along Embassy Row. "But men always want women to be this decoration, like you are this remote control that they can turn on and off. It took so much courage for Salwa to resign. To meet her is like spending time with your role model." This year's ceremony brings together many of the female leaders who emerged during the Arab Spring. It also includes Mexican anti-corruption politician Ruth Zavaleta Salgado and Liberian girl-soldier rehabilitator Rosana Schaack, who observed the need when she was working as a nurse during the country's civil war. It has been the kind of week when Samoan entrepreneur Adi Tafuna'i, who works with female farmers to sell the country's organic coconut oil to the Body Shop, could be seen discussing the power of women in business with Samar Minallah Khan, a documentary filmmaker from Pakistan who focuses on her country's discrimination against women. "It does feel like a bit of girl bonding, but with superwomen, since each of the women have their own power and strength," said Khan, who brought her 14-year-old daughter, who removed her generation's omnipresent earbuds to take it all in. The women photograph a statue of Eleanor Roosevelt during a stop at the Franklin D. Roosevelt Memorial. They say that they are amazed at how effectively the United States is able to market its short history and that their own countries should do a better job of honoring female leaders. Vital Voices was started in 1997 by first lady Hillary Rodham Clinton and then-Secretary of State Madeleine Albright to identify and empower emerging female leaders. It has trained more than 12,000 women from more than 144 countries. Presenters at this year's 11th Annual Global Leadership Awards include such luminaries as Tina Brown, Mariane Pearl, Chelsea Clinton, Diane von Furstenberg, Claire Shipman and Sen. Kay Bailey Hutchison (R-Tex.). The ceremony coincides with the release of "Vital Voices: The Power of Women Leading Change Around the World," a book by Alyse Nelson, the group's president and chief executive. She tells the stories of the international female leaders she has spent time with during her two nearly decades with the organization, including Kenyan Rebecca Lolosoli, who runs Umoja, a women-only village for those fleeing abuse; Somaly Mam, a former sex worker in Cambodia who now helps women in the same situation; and Marina Pisklakova, who started Russia's first domestic violence hotline. The book reads like a global management guide, but one that draws its anecdotes from women who have been agents of social change in male-dominated societies.           During a stop at the Georgetown waterfront, Zavaleta - a Mexican politician and former speaker of the house of representatives who exposed widespread corruption within her party - encouraged Shaack to run for office. "I really want to try," Shaack said, asking a slew of questions. The new friends also brainstormed about how to honor the one woman who couldn't make it to the ceremony to receive the organization's Global Trailblazer Award. Manal al-Sharif, 33, is a Saudi who was imprisoned after filming herself driving. She posted the video on YouTube and is now leading a national campaign to overturn the Saudi kingdom's ban on female drivers. She was scheduled to attend the event, but opted not to because she was concerned about her ability to leave and reenter the country without facing repercussions. (Sharif has been under increased pressure after a speech she gave last month at the Oslo Freedom Forum that was critical of the Saudi dictatorship.) "We revolt twice as women in our societies," Harazi observed. "But I know as a group we will find a way to give attention to her struggle.
